Headline: Barron's(7/30) Asian Trader: Korea's Stealth Rally
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Most foreign investors have missed the stealth rally in South Korea, where shares have shot up 36% this year, despite last week's beating.   This month, Bear Stearns Asia strategist Michael Kurtz upgraded Korea to Overweight. Seoul is deregulating financial services, and tensions with North Korea have eased. Some even see signs of an incipient recovery at bellwether Samsung Electronics (ticker: 05930.Korea) if demand for flat-panel displays and phone handsets stays strong.   Last week, the benchmark Korea Composite soared, as Moody's upgraded its rating to double-A and the won jumped to a multiyear high of 9,138 to the dollar. Korea remains cheap when compared to its neighbors, but it's always cheap -- and multiples have expanded sharply.   Korea trades at 12.6 times expected earnings, versus a five-year average of 8.1. In contrast, the region trades at 15.5 times, compared with a five-year average of 12.3. This situation exists even though foreigners have continued to sell. They now own roughly 36% of the market, after a high of 42% in 2004, which was followed by disappointment when Korea lagged in 2006.   The Bank of Korea has squeezed credit to its tightest level in six years as lending to smaller businesses has surged. Now, "the main risk is monetary-policy overkill," writes Nomura International strategist Sean Darby. Some investors fear that if U.S. stock-market volatility stays strong, Korea and other Asian markets will be clobbered (see page 17).   Korean multiples look pricey. Shipbuilders now trade at 2.63 times book value, versus 2.16 times two months ago. Citigroup nonetheless has boosted price targets and earnings forecasts for Hyundai Heavy (009540.KS), Hyundai Mipo (010620.KS), Daewoo Shipbuilding (042660.KS) and Samsung Heavy (010140.KS).   David Semple of the Van Eck Emerging Markets Fund (GBFAX) has cut his Korean holdings. "It's not to say there isn't a decent story, but while the stocks have doubled, the earnings upgrades are just 20% to 30%," he says. "You're going to have to wait for earnings to catch up. It's tough to see why large-caps should be rerated further."     The Philippines, UBS economist Jonathan Anderson wrote last week, "has produced an absolute financial market 'hat trick' in Asia -- the best-performing currency, the best-performing onshore bond market and (with the exception of China's A-share market) the best-performing equities"over the past two years. Why? Budget spending has stabilized as a share of the economy, and overseas Filipinos are flinging ever more money home, lifting the peso.   How much further can the rally go? There are certainly still some good plays, like commercial real-estate developer SM Prime (SMPH.PH). Van Eck's Semple likes a residential and resort developer, Megaworld (MEG.PH). And even lackluster San Miguel (SMC.PH) may unlock value at last by spinning off its domestic beer unit. For now, though, says Scott McDonald of Aladdin Caital, "the main focus is likely to be what happens outside the country."   ---   E-mail: leslie.norton@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Bajaj Auto Confirms Preliminary Talks With Renault
Story: NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--Bajaj Auto Ltd. (500490.BY), an Indian maker of two- and three-wheeled vehicles, confirmed Saturday that it's in early talks with French car maker Renault SA (13190.FR) to jointly study business potential for budget vehicles in India, a Bajaj statement said.   Upon favorable conclusion of the study, Bajaj and Renault could forge a long-term partnership to execute their business goal, the statement said.   On Thursday, Renault's spokeswoman had confirmed that the company had held preliminary talks with Bajaj Auto about a possible project to build a budget vehicle costing about $3,000.       -By Abhrajit Gangopadhyay; Dow Jones Newswires; 91 9831241778; abhrajit.gangopadhyay@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 08:08 ET (12:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Guyana Official:UN To Rule On Rift With Suriname Over Oil Basin
Story: GEORGETOWN, Guyana (AP)--Guyana's foreign minister said Saturday that he expects a U.N. tribunal to rule next month on a feud with neighboring Suriname over the rights to an undersea basin that could provide oil riches.   Rudy Insanally said the U.N. International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea is reviewing oral and written ownership claims to the basin, which experts estimate may hold 15 billion barrels of oil and natural gas.   "We are led to believe, after speaking to our legal teams, that the award by the tribunal is likely to be made in August," Insanally said in a statement. He said a specific date has not been given and did not provide any further details.   Guyana sought a definitive ruling from the tribunal in 2004 after talks with Suriname broke down over sharing any production from the basin, which stretches hundreds of square kilometers from the coasts of both countries.   The dispute brought Guyana and Suriname close to war and has blocked fuel exploration.   Suriname expelled Toronto-based CGX Energy Inc. (OYL.U.V) from the basin in 2000, halting its oil exploration under a Guyanese license.   CGX Energy, Spanish-Argentine company Repsol YPF (REP) and Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) recently met with Guyana's president to discuss exploring the basin in anticipation of the tribunal's ruling.   Surinamese officials could not immediately be reached for comment Saturday.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 16:05 ET (20:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:Reliance Indus 1Q Net +28.2% On Refining Margin Boost
Story: (Adds details and analyst comment)       By Abhrajit Gangopadhyay and John Satish Kumar     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)-- Reliance Industries Ltd. (500325.BY), India's largest company by market capitalization, reported Saturday a 28.2% rise in net profit for the fiscal first quarter, driven by strong gross refining margins and robust growth in its polymer business.   Net profit for the April-June quarter totaled INR32.64 billion, up from INR25.47 billion a year earlier. Its revenue in the just-ended quarter rose 6.1% on year to INR294.93 billion from INR261.66 billion.   The result was above the average estimate of six analysts polled by Dow Jones Newswires who had pegged net profit at INR30.82 billion on revenue of INR277.96 billion.   The refining and petrochemicals company said its gross refining margin, or GRM, for the fiscal first quarter was $15.40 a barrel, up from $13 per barrel in the fourth quarter and above $12.40 a barrel a year earlier.   GRM is the difference in the cost of the refined product and the cost of buying the crude for refining.   "GRMs expanded on the back of inventory gains, which we estimate, accrued at around 50 cents-70 cents to a barrel, while the operational margin per barrel could have been between $14.7 and $14.8," said S. Tulsian, an analyst and member of the National Stock Exchange.    Refining revenue in the just-ended quarter rose to INR227.94 billion from INR208.62 billion a year earlier. Revenue from petrochemical operations grew to INR108.44 billion from INR99.87 billion a year earlier.    RIL, which started as a textiles and petrochemicals company, has seen its refining segment emerge as a core business, contributing over 70% to the company's revenue.    Earnings before interest and taxes, or Ebit, from the refining and marketing segment rose to INR25.58 billion in the just-ended quarter from INR20.35 billion a year earlier, the company said.   Ebit from RIL's petrochemicals business also rose 36.2%  on year to INR14.81 billion from INR10.87 billion.   "The strong polymer growth was really surprising, since we all thought that polymer cycle is on a downward trend," Tulsian said.   Reliance expects demand for polyester to increase on the back of high cotton prices.   Quarterly earnings before interest and tax margins for the refining segment expanded to 11.2% from 9.8% a year earlier on higher GRMs.   Ebit margins for the petrochemical segment expanded to 13.7% from 11.1% a year earlier.   The company said total crude oil processed during the just-ended quarter was 8.01 million tons.   However, Reliance warned that local marketing margins remain under pressure.   In the domestic market, RIL had to keep prices of gasoline and diesel above those set by the state-owned oil marketing companies to minimize itsso-called "under-recovery," - the difference between the market price and the selling price.   India's oil companies have been selling diesel, gasoline, kerosene and liquefied petroleum gas below market prices as the government tries to keep inflation under control.   As a private-sector company, RIL doesn't have to abide by government directives on petroleum products' prices, but it tends to price its products on par with state-run firms to remain competitive.   The company is trying to focus on exports to overcome the challenges from local market.   During the last quarter, RIL exported 5.04 million tons of petroleum products and recorded export revenues of $3.2 billion. Reliance didn't give comparative figures.   Total expenditure increased to INR228.8 billion from INR202.8 billion a year earlier.   "The company is managing costs better, and we expect that it would expand its net operating margin to around 19% for the current fiscal year," Tulsian said.   Reliance's fiscal first-quarter margin expanded to 18.5% on year from 17.3% a year earlier.    Chairman Mukesh Ambani is the elder of two brothers who inherited the Reliance businesses founded by their father, Dhirubhai Ambani.   When the group de-merged in early 2006, the younger brother, Anil Ambani, took over the power, finance and telecom interests, while Mukesh took charge of the petrochemicals, refining, and oil exploration and production businesses.       -By Abhrajit Gangopadhyay and John Satish Kumar, Dow Jones Newswires; 91 9831241778; abhrajit.gangopadhyay@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 11:08 ET (15:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Northwest Airlines Cancel More Flights Sat, Cites Pilots
Story: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)--Northwest Airlines (NWA) canceled more flights as expected Saturday, with the company continuing to attribute the problem to pilot absenteeism.   Northwest did not release its own cancellation figures Saturday, but the Web site FlightStats.com reported that it had called off 138 flights as of 3:30 p.m. EDT. It reported that 680 scheduled flights departed.   The airline had canceled a total of 125 flights Friday, the Web site reported.   Northwest expects to complete 93% of its flights Saturday, said Roman Blahoski, spokesman for the carrier. The pilot absenteeism was affecting flights mainly on narrow-bodied aircraft, he said.   The airline had warned Friday that it would probably cancel more flights over the weekend.   The Northwest branch of the Air Line Pilots Association released a phone message to members Friday stating that it didn't believe there had been an improper use of sick time. If there was, the union suggested, it was caused by stress from increased flying hours.   The union has maintained that Northwest doesn't have enough pilots to fly its full schedule.   Northwest canceled more than 1,000 flights the last week of June, citing pilot availability and other factors, and announced this month that it had thinned out its July schedule and cut its August schedule by 4% to try to prevent a repeat.   The carrier also began recalling furloughed pilots and said it expects to hire 200 to 250 pilots in the next year. Furloughed pilots must be retrained before they can resume flying.   ---   On the Net:   FlightStats: http://www.flightstats.com   Northwest Airlines: http://www.nwa.com       (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 15:59 ET (19:59 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Bond Funds Gone Wild? A Pension-Plan Dilemma
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jacqueline Doherty   For years now, pension funds have faced a dilemma: The interest rates on their bond assets have fallen to historic lows, while liabilities -- the pensions they pay out to retirees -- have ballooned. As a result, many funds have taken on more risk to boost returns.   In this long-running bull market, adding riskier assets to a portfolio has paid off, but some critics fear pension managers may have gone too far. Chriss Street, treasurer-tax collector of Orange County, Calif., is one such critic, and the object of his concern is his own county's pension fund.   Street was elected treasurer last fall, and joined the board of the Orange County Employees Retirement System in December. For the past six months, he has been trying to convince OCERS that the county's pension plan, which is only 74% funded, has taken on too much risk. OCERS, he charges, has granted bond-fund behemoth Pimco, of Newport Beach, Calif., too much latitude in investing the fund's core bond portfolio, while its allocations to alternative assets such as hedge funds and commodities have grown too large.   "Orange County is in no position to invest in high-risk investments," says Street. "We should be conservative, because we're not playing with the house's money."   OCERS executives disagree, noting in a statement to Barron's that "OCERS is not taking additional risk to boost returns...and is willing to forfeit return for risk control . . . In reviewing the risk-adjusted returns, the portfolio is ranked in the top quartile of the Callan universe [an industry ranking] over the last three-, five-, seven- and 10-year time periods ending March 31, 2007."   Some in the county paint Street as a politician using scare tactics to score points with an electorate that remembers Orange County's notorious bankruptcy in 1994.   Yet, Street raises interesting issues that face many struggling pension plans across the country.   In a recent report, William Wechsler of Greenwich Associates (a Greenwich, Conn.-based financial-research firm) writes: "Public-plan sponsors understand that local governments can't tax their way out of this [under-funding] situation because the numbers are too big. "Instead," he continues, "they are trying to invest their way out of it with more sophisticated strategies. If they are able to generate returns that bring them close to where they need to be today, then the upcoming battles about how to fund their obligations will be later rather than sooner, and less harsh."   Orange County's pension portfolio, which returned 14% last year and 9% in 2005, is about 41% invested in domestic and international stocks, and 35% in fixed-income assets, including foreign bonds and TIPS (Treasury inflation-protected securities). Almost 25% of the fund is in alternative assets -- well above the average public-pension fund's 10.6% stake. Street is concerned about what theoretically is the safest portion of the county's bond allocation, a $532 million account managed by Pimco.   A core bond portfolio typically invests in dollar-denominated corporate and mortgage-backed bonds and Treasuries, and is measured against the Lehman Brothers U.S. Aggregate Index, which holds only dollar-denominated, investment-grade bonds. Core bond-plus funds, which have grown more popular in the past decade, often invest a portion of their assets in high-yield and emerging-market bonds, and/or derivatives.   OCERS has given Pimco a core bond-plus mandate for more than 15 years, and in December broadened it to allow Pimco to invest in a wider range of securities including currencies, options and credit-default swaps -- although it set limits on the proportion of such assets the portfolio could hold. The fund yielded 5.3% as of March 31, and average credit quality was double-A-plus.   The potential problem with core bond-plus funds, critics say, is that the emphasis may be shifting to the "plus." In general, "the level of risk in core bond portfolios has increased over time," says Richard Ennis, chairman of Ennis Knupp + Associates, a consultant to institutional investors and editor of the Financial Analysts Journal. "They're increasing their exposure to areas that are opaque, and there's leverage involved. There is no way [for an outsider] to measure the risk being taken."   OCERS executives explain in an e-mail to Barron's that their updated guidelines "reflect the changes in the fixed-income markets and provide clarity as to the investable universe. For example, interest-rate swaps were approved, as the swap market, in many cases, is more liquid than the U.S. Treasury market."   It added that the pension board "has received education on derivatives" from various parties, and that "OCERS has confidence in Pimco's experience in the fixed-income markets and its conservative and disciplined investment process."   As of March 31, the OCERS core bond-plus portfolio had $275 million invested in short-term securities such as commercial paper and CDs. Another $241 million was in long-term debt, mostly triple-A-rated mortgage-backed securities. The portfolio had relatively few corporate bonds or cash Treasury bonds. Instead, it had futures positions in various short-term markets around the world, in an apparent bet that rates would fall worldwide.   The largest of these positions was in Eurodollar futures, with a notional value of $4.9 billion. The fund also had sold short $88 million worth of two-, 10- and 30-year Treasury futures. Other positions included swaps, options and investments in currencies such as the Brazilian real and the Polish zloty.   "[It is] predominantly an arbitrage portfolio that is tremendously involved with swaps, options and futures," alleges Street. "You've converted a core bond portfolio into something entirely different."   In a statement, Pimco says that it has had "a 25-year relationship" with OCERS to manage pension assets, and has used derivatives in its fixed-income portfolio "for approximately 20 of the 25 years." The firm notes that it employs derivatives in the OCERS portfolio "for substitution, hedging and overall yield-curve and duration management; our use of derivatives does not create economic leverage."   Pimco says portfolio volatility has been commensurate with the Lehman Aggregate since it began working with OCERS, while "tracking error" has been near 1%. "We will continue to manage these fixed-income assets prudently and consistent with OCERS' approved investment guidelines," it adds.     Pimco is known for using the futures market to get interest-rate exposure in lieu of simply buying Treasury bonds -- an approach that requires little cash but creates leverage. In the case of OCERS, the firm may be using Eurodollar futures to create the equivalent, or synthetic, of a two-year Treasury note. Investing in Eurodollar futures requires only a minimal deposit: about 0.5% of notional value, or in this case, about $25 million.   The Eurodollar position contributes about two years of duration to the portfolio's 5.8-year duration. (Duration is a measure of a bond's interest-rate sensitivity.) To create the same amount of duration with a two-year Treasury note, the portfolio would have to buy $500 million of notes. Using Pimco's approach, it still can have $475 million remaining with which to buy other securities.   Eurodollars are considered among the most liquid and least risky derivatives. A one-percentage-point move in the Eurodollar futures could mean a gain or a loss of about $12 million, or 2%, in the overall portfolio. On most days, Eurodollar futures move by only 0.01 to 0.10 of a percentage point. Every night the position is settled, and either cash comes into the account to reflect the gain or OCERS ponies up cash to compensate for the loss.   The problem with this arrangement lies in the possibility that OCERS could be left holding not an actual Treasury bond but an obligation to the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in the event that the markets seize up. While Street, the county's Treasurer, acknowledges that the failure of an exchange is a remote possibility, some large U.S. bond investors with whom we spoke cast the issue more philosophically. They believe that having exposure to financial exchanges in the case of Eurodollar futures, or banks and brokerage firms as counterparties in the case of interest-rate swaps, may be inappropriate for a so-called core bond portfolio, particularly one managed for the benefit of public pensioners.   "The core bond portfolio should [act as] an anchor for the entire pension fund," says Street, adding that it should not be so complex as to require a "model" to understand.   "Even the best models can fail," he says. "Wall Street is a graveyard of geniuses."   Street also takes issue with a $507 million TIPS portfolio Pimco manages for OCERS. It holds more than $1 billion of Eurodollar futures, as well as numerous swap contracts, corporate bonds, mortgages and a dash of foreign currencies. These instruments, he argues, "don't reflect the stated purpose of the asset allocation."   OCERS executives note that the fund must have at least 80% of its exposure from TIPS and can invest the remainder in other assets, depending on market conditions.   At Street's urging, the Orange County Board of Supervisors hired Strategic Investment Solutions, a pension-consulting firm, to review and report on OCERS' asset allocations, investment policies and procedures, and investment-manager selection and monitoring. The firm is expected to deliver its assessment in about three months.   Given the historically robust performance of the county's pension fund, it is hard to argue that Orange County has been hurt by liberalizing Pimco's mandate and taking on more risk. If markets turn, however, some pension funds that have embraced riskier assets may long for the good, old days of plain-vanilla bonds.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Streetwise: A Fast Bounce Might Not Be Best
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   In Woody Allen's Crimes and Misdemeanors, the insufferable TV producer character delivers this aphorism on comedic theory: "If it bends, it's funny. If it breaks, it's not funny."   Whether the stock market is bending or in the process of breaking will determine whether investors will be able to recall with laughter last week's 5% drop in the indexes.   Even from these reduced heights, it's possible for market bulls to look back on the late-February scare with a satisfied smirk, as a short-lived bend in a long-lasting climb.   Cosmetically, the recent slide and the prior one share some resemblances. Both came shortly after the indexes had printed new bull-market highs and were accompanied by ruptures in the bond market that raised fears of unwinding leveraged trades. And in each case, there were one-day Dow washouts with indiscriminate selling, record volume and a surge in protective-options buying.   Here are some differences. This drop came less than five months after the prior one. In the prior couple of years of this bull market the periodic pullbacks of 6% to 9% have come further apart. The seasonal backdrop, for what that's worth, is less favorable in late summer than in late winter. The rally up to new highs was narrower this time. And, naturally, this bull market is now even older.   A week ago this column offered a hunch: "Something ought to come along fairly soon to prompt a scare, and stress-test this rally again." What came along was a deepening of the erosion in corporate credit-market conditions. That these markets are opaque, over-the-counter and subject to the intricacies of untold species of "financial sin-novation" has led to a sell-first response.   The market has passed prior stress tests by making its peace -- through a corrective pullback and recovery to new highs -- with developments that at one time were thought to be the ultimate rally killers. The market has, in turn, proved to itself that it didn't need the Fed to cut rates, or oil prices to collapse, or Treasury yields to continue falling or corporate earnings growth to stay above 10% in order to march higher.   What will be required now -- if this is going to prove to be a mere frightening bend in the tape rather than a true break -- is for the market to show that it doesn't need the constant promise of leveraged buyouts and debt-enabled share buybacks to hold it up.   This would seem to be a stiffer test than the prior ones. The earlier episodes were more adjustments in perception about possible market catalysts. The seizing up of the corporate debt market for a prolonged period would remove one huge source of actual spending power for equities.   Just guessing here, but passing this test could come as, say, a huge strategic merger grabs attention from the LBO vigil, or as the big brokers close their August quarters without any balance-sheet blowups emerging.   It should be said that if we're now witnessing the start of a bear market, it would make for a rather unusual market top. Do tops usually come when corporate insiders have slowed their selling to a two-year low, as they did the past four weeks? When the retail investor hasn't been enthusiastically buying stocks and shoveling cash into equity funds? When large-stock valuations are merely in the high-neutral range rather than clearly overvalued?   None of those factors, mind you, would stand in the way of a '97-style whoosh lower if contagion evidence surfaces. That drop measured some 13% in 20 trading days. If repeated, the S&P would be back at October's level.   That same character from the Woody Allen movie claimed that "comedy equals tragedy plus time." The last drop was reversed awfully quickly, without a more prolonged bout of pain and worry. As much as an oversold bounce looks likely in the short term, a quick and effortless rebound might not be best.     CME Group (CME) and Interactive Brokers (IBKR) are two stocks built for this market. The firms feast on market volatility and are riding the secular growth in derivatives volumes.   CME (recently merged with CBOT) handled double its average futures volume on Thursday. Rich Repetto of Sandler O'Neill notes that after a similar volume spike in February and on June 27, CME shares jumped 10% or so in the next two weeks. Headline: Barron's(7/30) The Electronic Investor: For Once, A Favorable Exchange Rate
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Theresa W. Carey   Direct-access online broker Trade-Station Securities recently added foreign-exchange trading to its platform's capabilities. It's a nice complement to what already was a very powerful program for creating and testing strategies: The upgrade means customers can now develop and execute their own strategies for trading equities, options, futures and forex pairs on the TradeStation site, with access to up to 34 years of historical data.   In the past, some institutional investors would use TradeStation's (www.tradestation.com) technical analysis to develop their own trading strategies and then back-test them using its historical data before executing their actual buy and sell orders elsewhere. But, with the release of version 8.3, they don't have to leave: The capacity for anyone to trade -- at what seem like decent prices -- is built right into the software.   One of the key components in testing is an accurate strategy-performance report. That aspect of the program has been overhauled, with more information specific to foreign exchange, such as the computation of a rollover credit for currencies held overnight.   You can create a strategy that will enter a trade based on events, either in the foreign-exchange market or in other markets.   For example, the system allows you to execute a trade automatically when the price of the Nasdaq 100 tracking-stock QQQQ hits a predetermined level. Then you can define your exit point based on a specific profit target. The trades will occur whether you're online or putting your exchange-challenged dollars to work in a pricey Paris boutique. Don't worry: You also can set your account up so that you manually approve each trade before it's executed.   Data is provided in real time at no additional charge, and the base currency for the display is set by the customer. For example, if your account is funded in dollars, the calculations are in dollars even if you're trading other currencies. If you open an account in euros, it will be set up for euros. Your stop losses and profit targets are also defined in your base currency.   Extremely active traders have long favored the forex markets for, among other things, their liquidity and round-the-clock opportunities. TradeStation President Salomon Sredni says, "Forex is the most liquid market in the world, and one that appears to be growing for individual traders in the U.S. and abroad."   Typically, forex brokers don't charge an explicit commission, but they are effectively trading against their own customers. That's because they're displaying a much larger spread between the bid and ask prices than the actual market spread quoted by banks. The broker will absorb the smaller market spread but then base the customer's order on the wider one. This levy can lop off as much $30 to $100 per trade.   TradeStation's new platform takes a different approach. Its pricing plan offers tighter spreads, which appear to run $10 to $15 per 100,000 units for the most liquid currency pairs (the actual unit, or deal lot, size will vary with the currencies being traded). The firm also charges an up-front commission that ranges between $5 and $8.14 per 100,000-deal lot.   As a result, the customers get to trade forex pairs at lower cost, while automating their exit strategies.   Trades are executed through an independent foreign-exchange-services company, GAIN Capital Group (www.gaincapital.com), which acts as the counterparty for each transaction and as a liquidity provider to clients using its access to the interbank market.   You can also place orders manually, rather than relying on an automated strategy. This process can be streamlined by using hot keys, such as pressing F9 to enter a market buy or F10 to enter a market sell. The functionality is the same as for the stock, options and futures platforms, says product manager Aaron Walters. "It's the same product across the board, no matter what asset class you're trading."   TradeStation's software runs on Windows or Intel-based Macs with cross-platform systems such as BootCamp.   The platform costs $99.95 per month, plus real-time exchange fees that depend on the data you choose to access. (Forex data is free, however.) The platform fee is waived for traders who place orders for 10 or more round-turn lots or 100 round-turn mini-lots. Other fee waivers exist for active stock, options and futures traders as well.   The platform fee includes access to all of the TradeStation analytics and data feeds, plus access to OptionStation, which is an extremely powerful options-analysis program. TradeStation's fees were much higher a year ago; even if your trading activity doesn't get you the platform for free, the analytical power and data feeds are reasonably priced -- a bargain if your trading is profitable.     Penny pricing of options update: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced in June that early results from its Penny Quoting Pilot program, which launched at the end of January, suggest that the new system will lower trading costs for retail trades. (See "The New Penny Options," Barron's Dec. 4, 2006.)   We expected that result for the limited number of options included in the pilot -- but several online brokers have told us informally that they're seeing drops in trading volume for those options' underlying shares. The smaller spreads may mean market makers are avoiding those options.   Traditionally, options are priced in increments of a nickel, which means that a one-tick shift in price changes the overall cost of a single contract by $5. (Each contract gives the holder the right to buy or sell 100 shares of underlying stock.) Cutting the increment to a penny is intended to make a one-tick change alter the price by $1. The net result should be a cost savings to investors, as well as an opportunity to turn a profit on smaller price moves.   The pilot program was originally intended to last for a year or so. The SEC is now considering expanding the trial to include additional options while it decides whether to make penny pricing the standard.   So we thought we'd ask you, Barron's readers, whether the availability of penny options has made a difference in your trading habits. Have you been trading penny-priced options over the last six months? Let us know about your experience via e-mail at electronicinvestor@yahoo.com.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Ouch!
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Leveraged buyouts look dead for now, but the bull market may live on.   Stocks were crunched last week by the twin impact of LBO financing troubles and mortgage woes as the Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 585 points, or 4.2%, to 13,266, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index declined 4.9%, to 1,459. The Dow's drop came in three big chunks -- a 226-point drop on Tuesday, the headline-grabbing 311-point drop on Thursday and a disquieting 207-point loss on Friday. A littleover a week ago, the Dow stood at new high of 14,000.   While it may take time for the Dow and other benchmarks to regain their recent highs, the major indexes are apt to end the year appreciably higher. With the losses last week, the industrials are up 6% for the year and the S&P 500 has risen 3%.   Stock-market gains also have been melting away abroad, where both the U.K.'s FTSE index and Japan's Nikkei now are essentially flat. And emerging markets are clearly losing some luster (see story on page 17). But it's hardly time to throw in the towel on U.S. stocks. "We've gone from complacency to concern, but not to capitulation," says Byron Wien, chief investment strategist at Pequot Capital Management. "The year will turn out all right." Wien says the S&P could hit 1,600 -- or 10% above the current level.   What's the good news? Stocks tend to track earnings, and corporate profits generally are robust. U.S. companies are raising dividends and buying back record amounts of stock. The global economy is strong. S&P 500 operating profits probably were up about 7% in the second quarter and full-year earnings are apt to increase about 8%. The index now trades for 15 times projected 2007 profits, a reasonable valuation, given sub-5% Treasury yields.     Still, the impact of the virtual shutdown of the junk-bond and leveraged-loan markets, where LBOs get financed, shouldn't be minimized. Leveraged buyouts have provided crucial support for stocks, with $450 billion of LBOs announced so far this year, according to Thomson Financial. Lingering questions about deals could add volatility to the stock market for weeks to come.   It's unlikely that a sizable LBO will be announced between now and Labor Day, because the financing just isn't there. Banks and Wall Street firms already are committed to fund more than $200 billion of LBOs through year end. With the junk and leveraged-loan markets sickly and buyers scarce, the banks and investment banks with LBO loan commitments could be staring at billions of dollars in losses.   The financing mess has negative implications for Wall Street firms, major banks, private-equity firms, hedge funds and for a whole group of stocks that have been buoyed by LBO speculation, including Macy's (ticker: M), Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), Alcoa (AA), Dow Chemical (DOW), MGM Mirage (MGM) and nearly every major real estate investment trust. Activist investors, meanwhile, are apt to turn down the heat on corporate managements because the activist solution -- often an LBO of the target company or a large debt-financed stock buyback -- is now far more difficult to do.   Market dislocations often create opportunities, and this time could be no different.   In the risk-arbitrage market, where participants bet on the completion of announced takeovers, investors now stand to earn annualized returns of 20% or more if financing comes through and deals close on schedule by year-end, up from 10%-15% returns earlier in the year. Takeover arbs say the market now is as attractive as it has been since 1998. "At the end of the year, we'll look back on this as one of the great opportunities in my world," one arb told Barron's.   Among the notable LBO takeover situations are First Data (FDC), Hilton Hotels (HLT), Harrah's Entertainment (HET) and Clear Channel Communications (CCU). Potential returns also are high in arbitrage situations involving strategic buyers, such as A.G. Edwards (AGE), which is being bought by Wachovia (WB), and Alcan (AL), which agreed to be sold to Rio Tinto (Rio.U.K.). Investors attracted to the takeover arena can buy a basket of deal stocks or purchase one of several mutual funds, such as the Merger Fund (MERFX). The bet in the takeover-arbitrage game is whether banks will honor their loan commitments to private-equity firms, even if it means taking losses. So far, the banks haven't backed away.   The junk-bond market also beckons, because investors can now earn equity-like returns of more than 10% on a wide variety of corporate credits. Investors have the opportunity to buy junk debt with yields in the teens on such LBOs as Realogy and Dollar General. This debt is senior to equity contributions of the LBO sponsors that took these firms private.   As the outspoken Bill Gross, the Pimco bond guru and Barron's Roundtable member, wrote last week: "the tide appears to be going out for the leveraged financiers and in for the passive owl money managers of the debt market. No longer will double-digit LBO returns be supported by cheap financing and shameless covenants. No longer therefore will stocks be supported so effortlessly by the double-barreled impact of LBOs and company buybacks."   It's not surprising that Blackstone Group (BX) has been one of the biggest casualties of the recent selloff. Blackstone shares, which fell $1.65, to 24.30, last week, are 22% below their the IPO price of $31 a month ago and 31% below the first-day close of 35 on June 22. With the financing spigot now turned off, it's going to be very difficult for Blackstone and other private-equity firms to announce any new LBOs soon. If deal activity dries up, so likely will the ability of the private-equity firms to raise money for new funds.   Performance on existing deals also may turn out to be disappointing, given high levels of leverage. Linens & Things, a housewares chain, has struggled financially since its LBO last year, threatening the $650 million equity contribution by Apollo Management and two other firms. If the equity in many recent deals, including Realogy and Dollar General, were sold now, the private-equity firms would be facing losses. It'll be interesting to see how they handle this situation when they calculate their future fees. The betting is that private-equity firms will mark their holdings to "model," or to favorable projected returns, not to a lower market value.   The LBO financing market won't stay frozen indefinitely, but once money does begin to flow again, it's not apt to be on the generous terms that have prevailed until recently. No longer will private-equity firms be able to take companies private at 12 times annual cash flow and finance such a deal with debt equal to 10 times cash flow at a blended interest cost of 8%. The all-in cost of financing new LBOs could be 10% or more once credit becomes available. The math of 10%-plus financing makes highly leveraged deals less doable, which will mean fewer LBOs.   One of the fundamental problems facing the leveraged-buyout market is that banks and investment banks have committed to fund over $200 billion of deals that are due to close by year-end. The typical commitment covers not only an amount of debt but an interest rate, because an LBO sponsor doesn't want to do a deal without some comfort about debt costs.   The banks are in a bind -- and facing sizable losses -- because their loan commitments are at below-market rates. On a typical LBO this year, a bank consortium might guarantee issuance of a senior loan at a rate of Libor, or the London interbank offered rate, plus two percentage points, or about 7.5%. The subordinated portion of the financing might be guaranteed at a 10% rate. The banks guaranteed the LBO sponsor that the financing rate will be no worse than these pre-determined levels. If rates rise, the banks get stuck holding the loans, as has happened with the Chrysler deal.   The market for leveraged loans has dropped sharply in recent weeks with the LCDX index, a proxy for leveraged loans, falling to about 92 from 100. The index has declined as banks sought to hedge their exposure to existing leveraged loans on their books and future commitments.   This means that an LBO loan now yields 3.5 percentage points above LIBOR, or 9%, while subordinated LBO debt, typically junk bonds, carry yields in the teens. Given this environment, some banks have gone to private-equity firms and sought to renegotiate terms of as-yet-unfunded loans, but the banks have had little success.   Take Dollar General, which went private earlier this month in a $7 billion deal. Its senior bank loans, sold at 97, now trade at 91. The company issued two large junk-bond issues that are junior to the bank loan. The $1.1 billion of 10 5/8% senior notes, issued at 98, have fallen to 86, to yield 13.5% and the $725 million of subordinated notes, some of which is believed to be held by the underwriters, have dropped to 87, for a 14% yield.   So investors now can get equity-like returns on Dollar General's debt and be in a senior equity position to the LBO group, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. Dollar General couldn't have been taken private if the LBO sponsors had to pay anything near the current yields on its debt.   Some investors are betting that the depressed LBO loans and bonds issued by companies like Realogy, Freescale Semiconductor and Dollar General will prove to be good investments. Why invest in a private-equity fund when you can buy debt that is senior to private equity and get mid teens yields with no fees?   Financial stocks, already the market's worst major industry group, were hit hard last as investors worried about exposure to LBO loans and mortgages, as well as an end to the LBO boom that has proven so lucrative to the major Wall Street firms. It seemed like hundreds of banks and thrifts littered the list of stocks making new 52-week lows last week as many stocks, including Apple, Amazon.com and Boeing, were hitting record levels.   Citigroup (C) fell 7.4%, to 46.97; Bank of America (BAC) declined 2.2%, to 47.41; Goldman Sachs (GS) was off 6.5%, to 192.65, and Lehman Brothers (LEH) fell  5.5%, to 64.50.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Air India Eyes 60-Jet Buy; Selection Process To Start Mid-Aug
Story: NEW DELHI (Dow Jones)--State-run carrier Air India said Saturday it plans to buy about 60 new commercial passenger aircraft over the next few years and aims to start the selection and purchase process by mid-August.   Air India, which is being merged with state-run Indian Airlines, ordered 68 Boeing Co. (BA) jets, worth over $11 billion at list prices, in December 2005 in a move to modernize its aging fleet.   "We will need to order about 60 plus more planes, but this is just a rough estimate," Air India Chairman V. Thulasidas said without giving a timeframe. He was speaking to reporters on the sidelines of an event marking the delivery of the first aircraft from Boeing.   Separately, Indian Civil Aviation Minister Praful Patel said the aircraft selection process is likely to begin in a fortnight.   "The whole plan will be evaluated for requirements like extra wide body aircraft ," Patel said.   According to industry officials, it takes up to four years for an aircraft to be delivered after the purchase order is confirmed.   India's aviation industry expects to grow by more than 25% annually over the next few years as a rapidly expanding economy boosts incomes, making it an attractive market for local and international carriers.   Around 60 million Indians traveled by air in 2006, and this is expected to increase to 100 million 2010.   Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh on Saturday formally launched Air India's new fleet, including its freighter service, at an event marking the delivery of the first planes from the Boeing order - two 777-200LR aircraft.    The 68-plane order comprises eight 777-200LR Worldliners, 15 777-300ERs, 27 787-8 Dreamliners and 18 next-generation 737-800 planes for its low-fare unit, Air India Express.   Air India will use the 777-200LR to become the first India-based airline to offer nonstop flights between the financial centers of India and the U.S. - Mumbai and New York - from Aug. 1, officials said.   In December 2005, Patel also said that as part of the Air India deal, Boeing will invest up to $100 million in India for setting up a maintenance, repair and overhaul complex and another $75 million to install four aircraft simulators.   Engine manufacturer General Electric Co. (GE) will also invest $20 million for an engine shop and another $10 million for training and other civil aviation requirements, Patel had said.       Merger To Boost Performance     In March, the government approved the merger of Air India and Indian Airlines in a move aimed at building a single airline to take on rising competition from both domestic and foreign rivals.   "There was a time when Air India was regarded as one of the world's best airlines. I am sure that Air India will once again regain that reputation," Singh said.   Legal formalities for establishing the National Aviation Co. of India Ltd. are expected to be complete in the first week of August, Civil Aviation Secretary Ashok Chawla said earlier this week.   National Aviation will run the merged airline - which will be called Air India to retain brand recall - and Air India Express.   When asked about recent media reports that the merger may be delayed as labor unions of the two airlines were unhappy with talks with the government on wage hikes and promotions, Chawla said the integration process will take time, but talks will go on.   "I have seen reports that some parts of unions have expressed a kind of anxiety. We are talking to them," Chawla said.    "The integration in terms of human resources will be spread over a long period of time and though this is going to take time, I see no difficulties."       -By Nitin Luthra, Dow Jones Newswires; +91-98100-65468; nitin.luthra@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 07:58 ET (11:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Italease Posts 1H Net Loss EUR387.7M, Calls Hldr Mtg Sep 8
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Italian leasing company Banca Italease SpA (BIL.MI) said Saturday that it posted a first- half net loss of EUR387.7 million as it had to pay EUR778 million to close derivatives positions, for a trading loss of EUR686 million.   In a statement sent to the Italian stock exchange,  Milan-based Italease also said it will ask its shareholders for up to EUR700 million to cover derivatives losses, in accordance with last Monday's request of the Bank of Italy.   In 2006 the Italian lender posted a first half net profit of EUR74.3 million.   Earlier this week the Italian central bank has also forbidden Italease from selling structured products and derivatives.   Italian merchant bank Mediobanca SpA (MB.MI) - a long time advisor of Italease - is expected to be the sole underwriter of the rights issue.   Italease shareholders will meet Sept. 8 to vote on the capital hike, Italease said Saturday. In accordance with a previous Bank of Italy request, the entire board of Italease will resign on the day of the shareholders meeting, with the exception of Massimo Mazzega and Franco Nale, appointed in June, and auditor Attilio Guardone.   McKinsey & Co. will help Italease's new top management and board in drafting a new business plan, the bank said.   Italease's share price has plunged since the company said May 31 that its potential exposure to losses from financial derivatives contracts jumped to EUR400 million by the end of May from EUR225 million at the end of December.   Friday, the stock closed at a new record low of EUR15.70.   Separately, following a July 5 filing of an official complaint by Italian consumer rights organization Adusbef against Italease, Milan prosecutors have opened an investigation for alleged fraud, people with knowledge of the situation said.   Board members of Italease may be questioned in the next days as witnesses, the same people said.   -By Sabrina Cohen, Dow Jones Newswires, +39 02 58 21 9906; sabrina.cohen@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 06:16 ET (10:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Follow-Up: GPS Giant Garmin Keeps Driving North
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   "Mrs. Garmin knows where she is going," insists my five-year-old niece, referring to the synthesized female voice of the portable navigation system in our car.   So, it seems, does Garmin (ticker: GRMN), a leading manufacturer of global-positioning systems, whose shares have rallied more than 150%, to a split-adjusted 84.36 from 33, since we profiled the company positively last year ("Finding True North," Feb. 27, 2006).   That increase is more than justified by booming sales of GPS units for cars in the U.S. and Europe, and more gains are likely to follow. Garmin's revenue jumped 73% to $1.77 billion in 2006, while earnings per share, which we daringly had suggested might rise to $1.77 from $1.43, instead hit $2.35. This year, Wall Street expects the Cayman Islands-based company to earn $2.89 a share, followed by $3.28 in 2008.   Jeff Evanson, an analyst at Dougherty & Co., thinks Garmin's shares could run up to 93 in the next 12 months. In a recent report on Garmin, Evanson noted that sales of personal-navigation devices continue to soar; there is untapped opportunity in the marine and aviation markets; Dutch rival TomTom is struggling to gain market share in the U.S. (where Garmin controls 50% of the market), and Garmin has yet to reap the benefits of its relationship with Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), through which it began selling a wide range of GPS units earlier this year.   To be sure, Garmin has attracted skeptics as its shares have soared, including Bank of America analyst Ron Tadross, who opined in a report earlier this month that the company's heady prospects already are reflected in its stock. Although Tadross predicts sales of portable navigation devices will continue to grow at an annual rate of 110% through 2009, he has a 12-month price target of 84. He sees growing challenges from other GPS players, and ever-cheaper GPS systems installed by auto makers.   Both risks in fact exist, but neither is new. Sony (SNE) gained negligible market share with an unimpressive GPS unit it introduced last year, while Garmin not only introduces less expensive products for the mass market periodically but continues to sell some of the best, most innovative units at the high end. Besides, even after months of record demand, the percentage of drivers who own GPS systems remains low.   For Garmin's shares, then, the directions are clear: Keep heading north.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Barron's Online: Renovating Home Depot
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Johanna Bennett   While the U.S. housing market remains troubled, Home Depot is rebuilding its prospects.   Shares of the nation's largest home-improvement retailer have slid more than 13% in the past two years, amid crumbling sales and profits, rising competition, shoddy customer service and the ouster of its CEO. Yet, Home Depot offers a compelling opportunity for patient investors. Its stock (ticker: HD), recently around 38, could double in the next three years, thanks to a mammoth corporate stock-repurchase campaign, store upgrades and gains in cash flow and profits.   "If you look beyond the current housing environment, Home Depot remains a solid company," says Allison Fisch, an analyst with Pzena Investment Management.   Says John Buckingham, chief investment officer for Al Frank Asset Management: "You want to buy a stock when it is on sale, and Home Depot is on sale."   Home Depot controls 16% of a $500 billion-plus global home-improvement market. Its more than 2,100 stores generated $79 billion in retail sales last year -- about 87% of the company's total revenues.   But because of a housing market that's expected to remain weak through 2008, Home Depot has cut its profit and sales projections three times this year. It's also struggling to correct customer-service problems that sent shoppers to mom-and-pop operations, as well as to arch rival Lowe's (LOW). Last year, sales at stores open at least a year fell almost 3%, and they could slip another 5% this year.   Chief Executive Francis Blake, who in January replaced embattled Robert Nardelli, has vowed to boost cash flow and reward shareholders. The company recently launched a tender offer for 250 million of its common shares at a price range of $39 to $44, in conjunction with a larger, half-completed program to buy back $22.5 billion of its stock. To help finance the repurchases, Home Depot is selling its HD Supply contractor-supply unit to private investors for $10.3 billion.   Home Depot also plans $4.5 billion this year in capital expenditures, a 29% hike over last year.   Existing U.S. stores will get about $2.2 billion to spruce up facilities, improve merchandise, add workers and lure professional contractors as customers. "I don't know many companies exposed to the housing market taking capital expenditures up 29%," says Home Depot's chief financial officer, Carol Tome. "But we are investing in the downturn so we can emerge even stronger."   It will take time for the investment to pay off. Home Depot says profits should fall 15% to 18% this fiscal year (which ends next Jan. 31), partly owing to the sale of HD Supply. But next year, same-store sales should rise and profits could climb 21% to $2.88 a share, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial.   Turnaround stories can be slow and dicey, especially for an aircraft carrier like Home Depot. But investors get a 2.35% yield from the dividend, which is expected to hit 90 cents a share this year. And if management can spruce up Home Depot, they'll be nicely rewarded.   Says Randall Haase, a portfolio manager at Baron Capital Management: "Once the cycle turns, this is a company that could earn $3.50 a share."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) In Beckham's Footsteps
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   A visitor to Tesco's unremarkable low-rise headquarters in Cheshunt, England, could be forgiven for thinking he's stumbled into a local community-college building -- instead of the home office of a global retailer with a $65 billion market capitalization.   There's no security squadron in designer uniforms, just a lone employee sitting at a bare-bones reception desk next to a small cafeteria. No time is wasted photographing the guest, who is asked to wait on a nearby leather couch, the one apparent concession to luxury. Or not; the sofa turns out to have a price tag attached and is part of the grocer's furniture line -- a vivid reminder that Tesco's all about retailing efficiency.   For the moment, at least, Tesco isn't well known in the U.S., but European investors recognize such frugality as part of the company's traditional "pile it high, sell it cheap" approach.   For years, a focus on shareholder value, customer needs and tight-fisted productivity served Tesco well, fueling strong, steady sales growth and propelling the stock to a nearly 200% total return since February of 2003.   This year, however, the market has been less impressed by the Tesco attitude. The London-based shares (ticker: TSCO.UK) are down about 14% since early May, to around 405 pence -- worse than the 5% drop in the FTSE 100 index, of which it's a member.   The American depositary receipts (TSCDY), which trade over the counter, are off less, by about 10%, to 25.50, thanks to the strength of the British pound. (The ADRs are equal to three ordinary shares.) Although it managed to record another healthy 11% revenue rise to 42.6 billion British pounds ($87 billion) in the fiscal year ended February, with earnings up to 23.3 pence per share from 19.9, the gains haven't been enough to make the market take notice again.     Why? Investors fret about potentially flagging consumer spending in the U.K., where Tesco makes about three-quarters of its sales. The Bank of England has pushed up interest rates over the past two years; the current key British repurchase rate stands at 5.75%, and it's expected to go higher soon. With mortgage payments, gasoline and utility prices all going up, many worry that the slight retail-industry slowdown seen in the second quarter will worsen as consumers tighten their belts.   And although Tesco has raised its U.K. retail-market share to a league-leading 31%, it's taking share at a slower rate than before. Another black mark: Comparable-store sales growth of 4.7% in the fiscal first quarter ended May 26 seemed pretty good, but fell short of the 5% that the City's analysts had penciled in.   What's more, tougher competition is expected from local rivals like J. Sainsbury (SBRY.UK) and William Morrison Supermarkets (MRW.UK), which have started to recover from several years of internal upheaval. Lately, U.K. food retailers have begun to cut prices, so the prospect of a bruising price war has caused some investors to bail out of Tesco's shares.   Investors' preoccupation with local market conditions, however, presents long-term buyers with the kind of bargain usually reserved for shoppers crowding Tesco's aisles.   The stock is now the cheapest it's been relative to peers in years. Even if the British consumer does begin to ease up on spending, that plays to Tesco's strength as the dominant retailer, and some savvy observers expect Tesco will reaccelerate market-share growth if consumers throttle back. And since food, a nondiscretionary purchase, remains about 80% of Tesco's U.K. sales, it's not too exposed to a potential cyclical downturn.   These worries also distract from the potential of Tesco's international stores, already about 25% of total sales and growing at roughly a 25% clip, triple the U.K. rate. Tesco has outlets in 12 other countries around the globe, including Ireland, Japan, China, Poland and Hungary.     Most notably, Tesco will launch its own British invasion of the U.S. this autumn (fast on the heels of soccer-megastar import David Beckham). America's been a graveyard for other British retailers, but Tesco's overseas successes strongly suggest it can make it here. If the current foreign-growth rate continues, the retailer should be able to lessen its reliance on the U.K., with international sales kicking in as much as 40% of sales in five years or so.   As British rate rises play out, the next quarter or two could become temporary speed bumps. But the stock looks to be undervalued by 20% or more, not including any material success in the U.S. And should Tesco find a nice niche here -- as some of the more fervent bulls believe -- then the stock could offer an even better return.   "Consumers in the U.K. have been a little challenged with interest-rate increases and higher gasoline prices," says James Moffett, a fund manager at UMB Investment Advisors, which holds about two million ADRs of the retailer. "[But] we're not getting distressed. . . . If anything, it's an opportunity to buy some more," says Moffett, whose funds have done just that in recent months. "Tesco has a good-quality long-term-growth record." His expectation is for 10%-15% earnings growth annually for the next couple of years.   Rosie Bichard, a London-based fund manager at Newton Investment Management, concurs. Tesco has a "relentless" focus on efficiency, she says, and its years of studying the U.K. consumer have helped it build a research capability second to none.   That homework now is paying off as Tesco takes share in nonfood items. In a slowdown, it should actually do better because of its dominant position in food, its solid balance sheet and generally cheaper prices, she says. Newton owns about 14.65 million Tesco shares, according to Thomson Financial.   For all the hand-wringing about British consumers, they don't seem to have closed their wallets, even after two years of interest-rate hikes. The British Retail Consortium says comparable U.K. retail-store sales rose 3% in June from the year-ago month, up from 2.3% growth in June 2006. Growth in the second quarter of 2007, however, averaged 2.5%, down from 3.5% in the first quarter.   "The consumer economy is certainly a bit tighter," notes Bryan Roberts, an analyst at PlanetRetail, a London-based retail consultancy, "but it's still fairly buoyant."     The Big Five retailers in the U.K. --  Tesco, Asda (which is owned by Wal-Mart Stores [WMT] ), Sainsbury, Morrison, and Marks & Spencer Group (MKS.UK) --  are enjoying good same-store growth rates, Roberts points out. For these folks growth is still available in nonfood areas like clothing, furniture and electronics, as well as in food products such as organic items, he adds. Those happen to be categories that Tesco's been pushing.   PlanetRetail is forecasting respectable 3.5% to 4% rises in U.K. retail and grocery spending through 2012. "The Big Five go at each other hammer and tongs in terms of pricing," says Roberts. However, "Tesco is the strongest and most competitive brand."   Market-share data bear him out. Taylor Nelson Sofres, a London consumer-research outfit, says that for the 52 weeks ended June 17, Tesco's market share among major grocers rose 0.8 of a percentage point to 31.4% -- roughly equal to the size of the next two, Asda and Sainsbury, combined.   Its slowing rate of market-share increases is partly a natural function of its already large food share, explains TNS analyst Chris Longbottom. Tesco can still raise its portion of the larger U.K. retail pie, Longbottom says. It remains the "Big Daddy" of U.K. retailing, with some two-thirds of British households shopping there in a typical four-week period, he notes. The figure for its nearest competitors is 45%.   Since Tesco is the U.K.'s biggest retailer and traditionally its price leader, rivals will have a tough time undercutting it. It has a wide range of store formats now, ranging from small Tesco Express convenience stores to big-box behemoths -- and the grocer is grabbing more and more sales of nonfood items such as armchairs, dining sets and clothes from its largest stores and its Website.   Home to nearly 2,000 of its 3,262 stores, the U.K. is the biggest part of Tesco's story, but it's becoming less important each day. The company's overseas growth is set to continue for several years, maintains Gertjan van der Geer, another fan of the retailer and a portfolio manager at Netherlands-based asset manager Robeco, which is overweight in Tesco stock.   In particular, there is significant room for growth in the U.S. convenience-store sector, which Tesco has targeted, says van der Geer. The stores will be called Fresh & Easy Neighborhood Market, each one occupying about 10,000 square feet, initially at locations in Los Angeles, San Diego, Las Vegas and Phoenix.   Failed attempts by British retailers such as Sainsbury and Marks & Spencer to muscle into American turf haven't deterred Tesco, which has slow fed details to the market. Observers believe Fresh & Easy will compete more directly with 7-Eleven, which has 7,200 stores here, than with major Western U.S. supermarket chains like Safeway (SWY). Both companies declined to comment on Tesco.   Tesco plans to commit about GBP 250 million ($500 million) a year over several years to get its U.S. presence up to speed. It could have 200 stores open here in relatively short order.   In a brief interview with Barron's, Tim Mason, chief executive of Fresh & Easy Neighborhood Market and a Tesco board member, said the stores will try to appeal to a wide variety of income levels, as they do in the U.K., but will be more than the "beer, chips and cigarettes" convenience store that Americans are accustomed to.   Indeed, Fresh & Easy won't even sell cigarettes; it will showcase "good-quality fresh foods," he says, with fewer processed foods, and no artificial colors or transfats. The store format will include prepared meals like chicken and pasta dishes, as well as pizza and salad, and also convenience items like health and beauty aids, and beer, wine, beverages and diapers.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Follow-Up: Indian 'Net Shares: Off, But Still Pricey
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   After Rediff.com, India's third-largest Internet portal, reported its June quarter last week, its Nasdaq-traded shares (ticker: REDF) were trading around $17, down from  more than 25 when we wrote skeptically about India's expensive Internet plays ("In India, Internet Shares Hardly Come Cheap," July 16). Sify (SIFY), one of India's largest broadband providers, traded at 7.50, versus 10.50 in mid-July. But these selloffs don't mean the stocks are cheap.   We argued Rediff's grip on its market was slipping as Google (GOOG) and Yahoo! (YHOO) make inroads in India. Also, we noted the makeup of Rediff's earnings raised questions, chiefly the big chunk that comes from interest on cash the company doesn't plan to spend soon.   Last week, Rediff revealed that it muffed its June quarter, with revenue of $6.8 million well below the $9.1 million estimated by the lone analyst who follows it. Earnings came in at seven cents a share, above Gilford Securities' estimate, but they were aided by the sale of a security.   Moreover, spending by the top 10 advertisers appears to have fallen from a year earlier, and there were other signs of weakness. Rediff chief Ajit Balakrishnan also highlighted competition from Google and Yahoo! and a growing presence in India of AOL and Microsoft (MSFT).   Intermittent takeover speculation has buoyed Rediff shares in the past. Yet Balakrishnan labels such rumors "completely untrue."   Sify, a smaller part of our story, is suffering from increased competition, too. Fees from franchised cybercafes are under pressure as the government encourages the building of more such establishments.   Are India's Internet shares now cheap enough to lure buyers? Says Ryan Jacob, who runs the Jacob Internet Fund and is a fan of Chinese Internet stocks: "I would probably have to have even more of a pullback to get interested."   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Judge Lets eBay Continue 'Buy It Now' Amid Patent Dispute
Story: NORFOLK, Virginia (AP)--A federal judge denied a request from a small Virginia company to stop the online auction powerhouse eBay Inc. (EBAY) from using a feature that allows shoppers to purchase items at a fixed price.   U.S. District Court Judge Jerome B. Friedman on Friday denied a motion by MercExchange LLC for a permanent injunction against eBay over the "Buy It Now" feature.   Last year, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that although eBay infringed upon MercExchange's patent for the service, it was up to the lower court to decide whether eBay had to stop using it.   In his ruling, Friedman said the company was not irreparably harmed because it continued to make money from its patents, either by licensing them outright or by threatening litigation against those it believed infringed upon them.   A federal jury found in 2003 that eBay had infringed on Great Falls-based MercExchange's patent and awarded the company $35 million. The amount later was reduced to $25 million.   MercExchange attorney Greg Stillman called the opinion a "double-edged sword."   "It was sort of good news, bad news for both sides," Stillman said. "I'm sure eBay is relieved that they're not going to be enjoined, but on the other hand (Friedman) made it quite clear that they're going to have to pay for that right."   Catherine England, a spokeswoman for eBay, said the company is "extremely pleased" with the decision.   Friedman denied eBay's request to stay proceedings on the "Buy It Now" patent because the infringement suit already has been tried by a jury and a final verdict and damage award was affirmed by the federal circuit.   The judge did stay proceedings on a second patent held by MercExchange until the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has time to reexamine it.   In the closely watched case, the high court ruled that judges have flexibility in deciding whether to issue court orders barring continued use of a technology after juries find a patent violation. The decision threw out a ruling by a federal appeals court that said injunctions should be automatic unless exceptional circumstances apply.   The case became a rallying point for critics who argue the U.S. patent system is riddled with abuse from small businesses that sue established companies to enforce patents for ideas that have never been developed into products.   On the Net:   http://www.ebay.com   http://www.mercexchange.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 01:39 ET (05:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Tech Trader: Yes, Microsoft Is A Growth Company
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   Is Microsoft still a growth stock? The Street sure doesn't seem to think so. Goldman Sachs noted in a report last week that large-cap-growth mutual funds are dramatically underweight in the software giant's shares; the average fund holds a 1.23% position, compared with Microsoft's 3.3% weighting in the Russell 1000 growth index. Goldman software analyst Sarah Friar asserted that the low level of enthusiasm offers "potential for significant buying if growth managers fearmissing the upside."   Alas, there's no sign that growth managers are changing their minds, though Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) is trying to shift investor thinking. At the company's annual Financial Analyst Meeting Thursday, company execs spent an extraordinary amount of time trying to convince people that Microsoft really is, yes, a growth stock.   The most recent numbers support their case. In the fiscal fourth quarter ended June 30, revenue rose 13% year-over-year, while earnings per share (before the recent Xbox 360 warranty-repair charge) were up 26%. The company's Windows business grew revenue 14%; the Microsoft Business Division, affectionately known as MBD, was up 13%; and the server and tools segment grew 16%. Even the troubled online segment saw revenue rise 9%, while the entertainment and devices business grew 28%.   And there's more growth to come. As CFO Chris Liddell pointed out, investors often assume that the company's size will make double-digit growth tougher; Microsoft raked in $51 billion in revenue in fiscal '07, after all. But, Liddell asserts, the company won't be contained by the law of large numbers, at least not yet. It sees fiscal '08 top-line growth of 11%-13%, operating-income growth of 12%-15% and earnings-per-share gains of 13%-16%. In effect, Microsoft expects to create another $5 or $6 billion company this year.   Still, the Street seems unconvinced. Many analysts and portfolio managers at FAM were skeptical when they walked into Microsoft's spacious conference center Thursday morning, and for the most part remained so when they walked out Thursday evening. I'll give you a sample of their cautious thinking in a moment, but first, let me tell you why Microsoft thinks the nattering nabobs are dead wrong.   For one thing, as CEO Steve Ballmer explained last week, the company essentially is adding two new businesses to its core competencies in producing software for the desktop and enterprise: It is entering the advertising business, in particular on the Web, and moving aggressively into the consumer market, where it already produces the Xbox, Zune music players and Windows Mobile software for mobile phones. Both areas, he says, provide opportunities for enormous growth.   Ballmer outlined seven areas where he thinks Microsoft can add at least $500 million in gross margin in the next three years:   - Corporate desktops   - Servers   - Office for consumers and small business   - The OEM personal-computer channel   - Online advertising   - Xbox 360 games accessories and services   - Windows mobile devices   For all these possibilities, the topic that came up again and again in presentations is "Software + Services," or the notion that Microsoft can extend the life of its core Windows and Office franchises by linking them to more services on the Web. The company talked extensively about merging the power of the desktop with that of the Internet "cloud."   This isn't something Microsoft sees as optional; it well knows that more computing will take place in the ether, and it doesn't intend to cede the turf to Google (GOOG), which may be the only company it really worries about when it comes to computing in the cloud. But neither can Microsoft take the position that running applications out on the Internet with no reliance on a desktop PC is a good idea; Windows and Office still generate mountains of cash.   There were several things the Street found disquieting in Microsoft's presentation. For one, Ballmer and some other execs said Microsoft's big, bold bets could take five or 10 years to pay off -- a time horizon way beyond the Street's quarter-to-quarter view. Also, there is a general consensus that the company overspends; nothing would delight analysts more than a nice big round of cost-cutting.   As Bill Whyman of ISI Group notes, Microsoft now has a variety of businesses in addition to Windows and Office that generate more than $1 billion a year in revenue. He thinks the company will build big businesses in advertising and devices, as planned, but the real question is how long it will take and how much it will cost. "There is a lot of frustration in this room," Whyman said during a break at the Thursday meeting. "Look at the businesses they will be in three years from now: a lot more competitive than the ones they are in today -- and a lot less profitable."   Trip Chowdhry, an analyst with Global Equity Research, thinks Microsoft's approach to the cloud is backward; he says the company is focused on building out infrastructure rather than generating the ingredients to attract a large audience. He cites Google and Facebook as companies that did it the right way.   David Pearl of Epoch Investment Partners thinks Microsoft will continue to return a lot of cash to shareholders via stock buybacks and, to a lesser degree, dividends. Liddell said the company bought back $28 billion of stock in fiscal '07, just $1 billion short of ExxonMobil's (XOM) record $29 billion buyback in 2006.   Mark Stahlman, a longtime tech analyst now with Gartner in New York, remains wary of Microsoft. He thinks the coming departure of Bill Gates as a full-time employee, with a shift in development responsibility to chief software architect Ray Ozzie, will not be a smooth one. Stahlman thinks the kinds of systems you need to roll out products in the cloud actually require the services-centered thinking of computer scientists like Ozzie. But the hacker culture at Microsoft, embodied in Gates, runs deep and could resist a change in approach.   Mary Meeker, the Internet and software analyst at Morgan Stanley, was one of the few people I talked with who came away feeling more upbeat about Microsoft's prospects. "They have more clarity on what they need to do than they've had in a long time," she says. "My confidence that they have a good strategy has increased, not decreased."   Meeker makes a good point: The strategy does make sense. What isn't as clear is how long it might take for the company to reach its goals. Microsoft may be patient, but Wall Street is another matter.   ---   e-mail: eric.savitz@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) New Amazon, Same Old Questions
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   Healthy revenue growth and improving margins catapulted Amazon.com's shares 17% higher last week, to 84, leaving the stock's many short sellers weak in the knees. That jump, topping off a mega-gain of 216% in the past 12 months, also stoked memories of the dot-com market of the late 1990s, "when you were scrambling around to find a metric to make the stock attractively priced," says Hamed Khorsand, an analyst at BWS Financial with a Sell rating on the shares.   These days Amazon (ticker: AMZN) has a metric -- earnings -- which helped set off last week's stampede. The online retailer, still led by Internet pioneer Jeffrey Bezos, said second-quarter profits nearly quadrupled to 19 cents a share, on sales of $2.8 billion, and gross margins, as closely watched now as losses once were, rose by 2% to 24.3%.   Revenues got a boost from successful low-price deals and Amazon Prime, which offers customers free two-day shipping for a $79 annual fee.
