Record orders for the new Harry Potter book generated added traffic and impulse buys at the company's Website, though the book's revenues won't show up until the third quarter. More third-party sellers in Europe and tighter spending also bolstered margins, making for a rosy outlook for the rest of the year.   As encouraging as these improvements are, Amazon's sky-high price-earnings multiples suggest investors' enthusiasm has gotten ahead of the company's growth potential, leaving the shares ripe for a markdown. Late last week Amazon traded for 78 times analysts' earnings estimates of $1.07 a share for 2007, and 56 times '08 estimates of $1.51. Even if the company achieves this anticipated 41% jump in earnings next year, it's hard to justify such a premium to its growth rate, especially when Internet peers such as eBay (EBAY), which fetches about 21 times 2008 earnings estimates on EPS growth of 16%, boast higher net operating margins.   Khorsand, a long-time Amazon bear, has a 12-month price target of 65 for Amazon shares, and an '08 earnings estimate of $1.46 a share.   Despite much talk about its evolution from Website retailer to e-commerce partner to "development platform," Amazon still gets 65% of sales and 62% of profits from selling books, CDs and videos. Another 32% comes from electronics and other merchandise. About two-thirds of sales are generated in North America, with the rest largely from France, Germany and Japan. Sales by third parties have grown to about a third of revenue.   The big question now is whether the Web warrior can sustain profit-margin growth while ramping up to sell the "earth's biggest selection" of products. It will have to meet shipping expectations for third-party sellers and battle digital-media competitors like Apple's (AAPL) iTunes, Napster and other content providers. In addition, international growth brings greater regulatory and currency risk. And, Amazon must spend to promote its new Web-based technology services to customers ranging from small venture-capital firms to media giants.   "On a lot of items, Amazon is not making much margin," says Darren Chervitz, director of research at the Jacob Internet Fund (JAMFX), which owns eBay shares but not Amazon. Chervitz recently purchased a big-screen television on Amazon.com that was roughly $1,000 cheaper than rivals were offering, and he got white-glove delivery and installation. For that, he loves his Amazon experience. But not the stock. "The consumer can always be a click away from your competitor, so it is a never-ending game of sacrificing profit to make the consumer happy," he says.   Says a fund manager who's short Amazon and prefers anonymity, "We actually think you could see 50% downside from here -- a big move, but keep in mind the stock was just there not more than six months ago."   Although Amazon has bolstered its margins in the past year, "Wall Street has extrapolated that improvement for the next five years . . . [and] we really do believe there is a brutal natural limit to their margin," this manager says. "As we start to get a tiny bit closer to it, there is going to be a lot of heartache and disappointment."   The operating margins needed over time to maintain the current stock price are "unobtainable," says Mark Mahaney, an analyst at Citigroup Global Markets who was among the few Wall Street skeptics in a sea of upgrades last week.   International third-party sales growth will be offset by modestly declining U.S. gross margins, and core expenses -- marketing and fulfilling orders, including the cost of shipping -- could vary greatly, Mahaney says.   An Amazon spokewoman refused to comment or provide access to company officials.     Given the stock hype of late, investors should be aware that Amazon and Wall Street analysts move freely between earnings numbers that reflect standard accounting rules -- $1.07 is the estimate for 2007 -- and those that exclude items such as restricted-stock compensation --  $1.51 for this year. The latter exercise obviously makes Amazon's valuation look less expensive, and is commonly used to evaluate tech companies. But Amazon remains obligated for stock-based compensation, which has been on the rise but is absent from so-called pro forma numbers.   Mahaney's 12-month price target is 85, near the current price, based on a multiple of 60 times his 2008 estimate, a penny above Street estimates, and 25 times his estimate for 2008 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, of $3.08 a share.   "One of the issues on the stock is, will they have to have that aggressive R&D ramp-up again?" Mahaney tells Barron's. "Given they have 60%-70% of sales and profits in media, they will have to keep inventing, hiring people to improve the interface. And they still don't have a full-fledged music-download piece on their site."   Khorsand sums it up this way: "Amazon doesn't have any new technology to change society, like the iPod did."   The company is planning a new music service that will be free of some of the rights restrictions that can limit downloads. Reducing downloading hassles could steal market share from iTunes and Napster.   In Amazon's recent earnings conference call with analysts, Bezos told Mahaney that it's too early to discuss music and video efforts. He talked up Amazon's Web services for corporate software developers who need Internet storage, computing and other functions instead. He also said third-party sales have great potential, since Amazon can give small sellers the technological skeleton for free shipping, gift wrapping and other Amazon perks.   The bulls, who if nothing else rightly fear betting against Amazon's amazing momentum, have their own ammunition. The shares' valuation has come down considerably over the past five years as earnings gained traction and the company started to expand overseas. What's more, at their five-year peak, the shares were trading at a much pricier 165 times forward earnings.   But if gross margins fray just a bit in coming quarters, the stock is likely to experience its own fire sale.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) In Beckham's Footsteps -2-
Story: Mason adds that Tesco is having "very productive conversations" with major drug-store retailers, like Walgreen (WAG), about potentially developing sites together. He hopes to have 200 Fresh & Easy stores open during 2009, and the U.S. effort is expected to reach the breakeven point by the third full year of operations, which would be November, 2010.     Bears on Tesco shares argue the company will misstep. Yet even in a worst-case scenario, a failure here wouldn't inflict too deep a wound, contends David Boyle, pan-European equities manager for Aberdeen Asset Management, which holds Tesco stock. Given Tesco's size -- it generated GBP 3.5 billion in cash last year -- the U.S. investment is relatively small. "Tesco is so big that it could take that GBP 250 million, throw it into a pit and burn it, and no one would notice," quips Boyle.   Unlike its British predecessors, which tried to replicate their home-turf formats, Tesco will succeed in America, he says, because it will build stores that suit U.S. consumers.   Not long after Tesco's February 2006 disclosure that it would land on the West Coast, Warren Buffett entered the picture. The legendary American value investor gave what is perhaps Wall Street's best investment imprimatur when his Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) investment vehicle purchased a 2.9% stake in Tesco last year through a subsidiary.   The U.S. doesn't even have to be a factor to make a good investment case for Tesco, says Robeco's van der Geer. It is one of the best food retailers in Europe at executing its strategy, yet one of the cheapest, he says. The U.S is just an option on growth, in the the view of the fund manager, who sees the current share price as a long-term buying opportunity.   With the recent drop, Tesco shares are selling at their biggest discount to rivals since 2002, says Tim Attenborough of Exane BNP Paribas; he recently raised his rating to Outperform from Neutral. At 405 pence Tesco's London-traded stock changes hands at about 16.3 times consensus earnings estimates of 25 pence a share for the current fiscal year, ending next February, and 14.5 times next fiscal year's estimates of 28 pence.   The stock is "very oversold," says Attenborough, who argues that the multiple contraction reflects sentiment rather fundamentals. He estimates Tesco's U.S. operations could generate sales of GBP 1.8 billion in five years and margins of 4.25% on earnings before interest and taxes, or Ebit, of GBP 77 million. If Tesco is successful with its first 200 stores, that could turn out to be conservative.   Zurich's Bank Julius Baer is another asset manager that has been adding Tesco shares lately. Baer analyst Andrea Gerst says U.K. retail fears already are factored into the stock price, but potential growth from the U.S. is not. Tesco sports U.K. Ebit margins of 5.8% and international margins of 5.2% to 5.3%. That's far better than the 4.5% average of the Morgan Stanley Capital International European Food and Staples Retail group. Tesco is 20% undervalued, figures Gerst, who adds, "the discount is unjustified."   That's likely to become clearer to the market as the next couple of quarters unfold. A U.K. retailing price war could certainly become an issue, but a bigger concern would arise if Tesco started to tart up its headquarters. Unless that happens, Tesco's shares look to be on sale for long-term investors.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Speaking Of Dividends: $15 Billion Gusher
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   The world's two largest offshore oil-and-gas drillers - Transocean and GlobalSantaFe - plan to unite. As a result, Transocean shareholders should bring in a $15 billion gusher.   The merger, which would create a $53 billion company under the Transocean name, grabbed the attention of Robert Willens, a Lehman Brothers managing director and tax expert, because it probably will be the nation's biggest tax-free return-of-capital distribution on record.   Assuming shareholder approval and regulatory clearances, Transocean (ticker: RIG) will acquire Global (GSF) for about $18 billion in Transocean stock and cash. Then, Transocean will retire its existing stock and issue to its shareholders a smaller number of new shares and some $33 in cash per retired share. Even though the cash and stock will be disbursed simultaneously, Willens observes, Transocean "is taking the position that the cash payout is a separate transaction" that should be evaluated as any special distribution would be. To Willens, this seems like a reasonable position under the tax law.   If the IRS agrees, Transocean shareholders will be sitting pretty. That's because the company "has a substantial deficit in retained earnings and therefore probably has a deficit in earnings and profits, as well." (E&P is a tax-accounting concept designed to measure a corporation's dividend-paying capacity.) So if Transocean doesn't generate any E&P in 2007, the entire $33 distribution will be a tax-free return of capital. "It's not often you see a return-of-capital distribution emanating from a merger," notes Willens, "and you certainly never see one of this magnitude."     The world's No. 1 brewer, Anheuser-Busch, Wednesday reported a 6% gain in second-quarter profit and increased its quarterly common dividend 11.9%, to 33 cents a share from 29.5 cents. This marks the 31st consecutive year of dividend enhancements by Anheuser (BUD). Disbursements have been ongoing since 1932.   Stockholders of record Aug. 9 will receive the new payout Sept. 10. The ex-dividend date is Aug. 7. Trading at about 49 on the Big Board, or six points under its 52-week high, the shares yield 2.72%.   "Led by U.S. beer operations, all of our business segments reported improved earnings in the second quarter," said CEO August Busch IV. For all of 2007, the company expects to exceed its long-term annual earnings-per-share growth target range of 7% to 10%.     Newspaper advertising linage is nothing to write home about, but Gannett, the largest U.S. newspaper publisher, posted an 18% gain in second-quarter profits by cutting costs and selling some publications.   Tuesday, Gannett (GCI) sweetened its dividend 29%, to 40 cents a share from 31 cents. The payment and record dates are Oct. 1 and Sept. 14, and the stock goes ex-dividend Sept. 12. Yield: 3.25%. Since 2000, Gannett has returned about $6.2 billion to investors via dividends and stock buybacks.   CEO Craig A. Dubow credited Gannett's strong cash flow and financial position for the dividend enhancement.The stock is trading around 50, down from a 52-week high of 63.50.     Despite a drop in second-quarter earnings per share, Reynolds American (RAI), the No. 2 U.S. tobacco company after Altria Group (MO), Wednesday hiked its quarterly common payout 13%, to 85 cents a share from 75 cents. That gives the stock a 5.45% yield. Disbursement will take place Oct. 1 to investors of record Sept. 10. The ex-date is Sept. 6. The shares, listed on the Big Board, are a bit under their 52-week high of 67.60.   CEO Susan M. Ivey said that the payout boost "keeps us in line with our policy of returning about 75% of our current-year net to shareholders" through  dividends. "Our total shareholder return since Reynolds American began trading as a public company three years ago exceeds 100%, far outpacing the return of the overall S&P 500." She added that Reynolds is "solidly on track" to deliver 9% to 12% profit growth this year.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) The Trader: A Big Market Selloff Without A New Surprise
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Momentum is essentially the difficulty of stopping an object, and it increases with the object's mass and velocity.   The stock market's sell-off last week certainly had both mass and velocity. The flight from stocks broke volume records at all three major U.S. stock exchanges. At the height of Thursday's dismay, stock indexes skidded more than 3% within hours. There was even a global reverberation, with the thud echoed in markets from Brazil to Britain.   What the sell-off didn't have was the sharp sting of a new surprise. Sure, there were some frightful scares (and no, it's not John Travolta in drag). A 6.6% drop in new- home sales fanned fears that the limping housing market will cripple the broader economy, but housing's woe has all the freshness of a rehashed musical. A $12 billion debt offering to finance the buyout of Chrysler from DaimlerChrysler (ticker: DCX) was spurned by investors, swelling the list of postponed deals that banks must now absorb. But a pickier credit market hasn't stopped stocks before.   Severe selling so soon after stocks reached record peaks points to one thing: the Dow 14,000 bash on July 19 was attended largely by the fretfully invested professionals well aware of the risks but afraid of falling behind any market rally. Too worried about missing any perceived fun, but too wise to stick around for last call, the throngs headed for the exit once it became clear others were leaving the party.   The ensuing scramble for the safety of bonds sent the 10-year Treasury yield to 4.77% Thursday, down sharply from nearly 5% just days earlier. That momentum carried over into Friday. While bond yields stabilized, another wave of selling in Friday's closing minutes quashed hopes that the exodus from stocks has let up.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average suffered its biggest one-week point decline in five years, losing 586, or 4.2%, to 13,265. The Standard & Poor's 500 tumbled 75, or 4.9%, to 1459. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 125, or 4.7%, to 2562, while the Russell 2000 gave up 59, or 7%, to 778.   Was there panic? Declining stocks outnumbered rising ones 10-to-1 Thursday. The pool of stocks skidding to new 52-week lows reached 783 Thursday, near the highest in 15 years, and Friday added 373. The broad selling "seems extreme" to Robert Pavlik, Oaktree Asset Management's senior portfolio manager. "Shouldn't it focus on the more speculative stocks" bid up on deal chatter? The vehemence of profit taking suggests, at the very least, a recalibration of the risk investors are now willing to stomach.   But was the panic extreme enough to suggest the worst selling is behind? Investors puked up stocks violently enough, but the puking was more ferocious in late February. The market's "fear gauge," as measured by the Chicago Board Options Exchange VIX volatility index, spiked slightly above levels reached in June 2006. Interestingly, option prices suggest traders expect the S&P 500 to gyrate even more than the historically volatile Nasdaq 100 --  a sign the financial stocks that populate the S&P 500 are a source of worry.   But a Street consensus also emerged quickly -- perhaps too quickly -- that this correction is both healthy and a buying opportunity. Stocks could tick higher from here, but it won't be because market anxiety has already peaked. Notes Miller Tabak's chief technical market analyst, Philip Roth: "Climaxes are final catharses after sizable declines. Traders cannot stand the pain any more and throw stocks over board." In 1987, for instance, stocks had slid about 20% only to hurtle down another 20% in a day. Today, stocks are above their March lows and a hair away from record peaks. "If we had a climax [Thursday], it was a mighty small one," says Roth.   Spreads on high-yield corporate debt have spiked more than 71% since June as worries increase about tighter credit and rising defaults. That's bad news for stocks, since the S&P 500 has fallen an average 9.6% in similar spikes over the past decade, says Bespoke Investment Group. The higher stocks' valuations when lending jitters hit, the fiercer the selling. In that regard, bulls will take heart in the market's current price/earnings ratio, which is modest compared with those prior stretches and which "implies that the current decline should be contained."   The diligent researchers at Bespoke also looked up precedents when the S&P 500 notched a 52-week high only to unravel suddenly. In 19 such instances since the end of World War II, the average decline was 8.94%, and the market needed 119 days to regain lost ground. Only once -- in late 1980 -- did it reach a new high before sinking immediately into a bear market.   "Simultaneous declines in both stock prices and bond yields" -- like that seen last week -- "are indicative of a recession," notes Jason Trennert, chief investment strategist at Strategas Partners. "But given an unemployment rate of 4.5%, improved capex expectations, strong export growth and the aggregate strength of corporate balance sheets, the chances of recession appear remote." At 6.7%, the market's forward earnings yield is still rich relative to the 4.8% payout from 10-year Treasurys, he notes, and should support stock buying.   The question, of course, is whether profits can keep improving enough to help stocks maintain their appeal. So far, second-quarter profits have increased 6.5%, ahead of the 4.3% growth analysts had forecast, but there are signs that bear watching. Countrywide Financial's (CFC) earnings flub hardly qualifies as a shock, but weaker-than-expected profits from Caterpillar (CAT) and ExxonMobil (XOM) ought to prove more worrisome. Can the momentum of global growth continue to propel the stalled domestic economy?   The brutal selling sent shares of Home Depot (HD) to 37. This, curiously, is below the 39-44 range at which the home-improvement retailer is trying to buy back some 250 million shares through a tender offer.   It isn't the only one. Charles Schwab (SCHW) dipped briefly below the 19.50- 22.50 range in which the discount brokerage is buying back 7% of outstanding shares. And at about 26.44, Expedia (EXPE) slumped  below the 27.50-30 band in which the travel-services company hopes to buy back stock.   Shawn Collins, a risk-arbitrage strategist at Citigroup, sees the market's reaction to Home Depot as opportunity. Over the past decade, less than 10% of such stocks have traded below the offer range just before the tenders expire. Each eventually was completed -- with 80% at the low end of the range and 20% higher than that.   Several factors drive Home Depot's descent. There is the panic over housing and mortgage weakness. Add to that the uncertainty over how the tender might be pro-rated, and worries about how the stock will trade once the tender is over.   Home Depot plans to finance about half of its enormous $22.5 billion buyback by selling a wholesale division to private equity investors. But, as Citigroup analyst Deborah Weinswig noted, "the tender is not contingent upon the sale of HD Supply, as committed financing is in place."   Meanwhile, targets of already-announced buyouts also saw shares drift well below their offers. To Goldman Sachs strategist David Kostin, this is both an irreconcilable inconsistency -- and opportunity.   "Stocks cannot both melt down because the market fears that financial institutions will have to fund and hold leveraged loan commitments, while at the same time [see] shares of target companies sell off on the belief that the same transactions will not close," he notes. The market assigns a roughly 62% chance that existing deals will close, but he thinks the likelihood is much higher. He suggested buying a basket of 22 targets, including First Data (FDC), Harrah's Entertainment (HET), Hilton Hotels (HLT) and TXU (TXU).   Let's begin with what passes for magic words at this moment: "Fortunately, unlike some of the larger firms in the securities industry, [we have] virtually no exposure to the subprime business."   They were uttered last week by Thomas James, chairman and CEO of Raymond James Financial (RJF), as the financial- services firm reported record quarterly profits. But even that reassurance and a 20% jump in net income weren't enough to stave off a 3% stock slide.   The market's indifference is understandable. At a time when investors are running after anything with overseas revenue, the St. Petersburg, Fla., firm boasts an unabashedly American footprint. And then there's that cursed word -- financial -- right there in its name.   In truth, its subprime-free aura isn't the only appeal. CEO James has been building its banking and asset-management operations, and that shift is "starting to click," notes Wachovia analyst Douglas Sipkin. Bank revenue increased 41% last quarter, and strong deposit growth continues to outpace loan production. Management recently guided up the bank's contribution to 2008 earnings to 19 cents a share from 12 cents, and that figure is projected to reach 35 cents a share in 2009.   Raymond James also will benefit, perhaps unexpectedly, from rival A.G. Edwards' (AGE) $6.8 billion agreement to be acquired by Wachovia (WB). Edwards brokers dissatisfied with Wachovia's retention packages have begun to prowl for greener pastures, and while any defections to the likes of Merrill Lynch (MER) or UBS (UBS) won't budge these behemoths' bottom lines much, they could bump up Raymond James' commission haul noticeably.   The firm has more than 4,640 financial advisers serving 1.6 million accounts, and productivity, following a spell of over-hiring earlier this decade, has been improving steadily. In the private-client group, revenue and assets per financial adviser have both risen more than 40% since late 2004.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Investors Oppose Rolling Back Sarbanes-Oxley Act - Survey
Story: By Judith Burns     Of DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)--Investors have more confidence in U.S. capital markets and corporate financial reports than in the past, and they oppose rolling back a 2002 law that tightened rules for corporate accounting, a new survey found.   According to the survey, 60% of investors are more confident in audited financial information issued by public companies than in the past, and 62% oppose easing the stricter requirements imposed by the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which was adopted amid financial scandals at big-name companies, including Enron Corp. (ENE) and WorldCom Inc.   About 1,000 investors took part in the telephone survey, conducted in mid-July for the Center for Audit Quality. The center, an offshoot of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, released the results in advance of the five-year anniversary of the law's enactment on July 30, which it will discuss Monday at an event that will include the bill's co-sponsors: Paul Sarbanes, Maryland's former Democratic senator and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, and Michael Oxley, a former Ohio Republican who chaired the House Financial Services Committee.   Complaints about the high cost of complying with the law, a major point of debate among policy makers in Washington, don't appear to be a critical factor for investors. Just 22% of those surveyed said the law should be eased to address concerns about its costs and any negative effect on U.S. competitiveness. Almost as many, 21%, said they would be very concerned by any easing of the law.   "Investors do have more confidence in the marketplace," thanks largely to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, said Center for Audit Quality executive director Cynthia Fornelli. She noted that only 5% of those surveyed said adopting the law was a bad idea, with 56% calling it a good idea.   One of the most controversial elements of the law, requiring public companies to conduct an annual assessment of their internal financial-reporting controls, with further review by the company's outside auditor, is extremely popular with investors, the survey found. Fully 76% of those questioned said they viewed that requirement as a positive change.   Requiring chief executives and chief financial officers to certify the accuracy of the company's financial results is seen as another positive feature, as is the law's requirement for public companies to have an independent audit committee hire, fire and oversee the company's outside auditor. Creation of a new oversight body charged with inspecting and disciplining public company accountants is a hit with investors as well, favored by 76%. Somewhat less popular but still drawing support from investors is a requirement that bars a company's independent auditors from providing consulting and other services to the company, which was viewed as a positive change by 64% of those questioned.   While such changes have helped boost investor confidence, Fornelli acknowledged there is still room for improvement, as just 38% of investors said they are quite confident in audited financial results issued by public companies. About 42% said they have some confidence and 16% said they have little or no confidence in such results.   Confidence in U.S. markets outstrips confidence in markets abroad, the survey also concluded. Overall, 39% of investors expressed a high level of confidence in U.S. capital markets, compared with 22% who say they are highly confident about markets outside the U.S.   The margin of error for the results is plus or minus three percentage points. The nationwide survey included investors in stocks, bonds, mutual funds and retirement accounts, including work-based 401(k) plans.   -By Judith Burns, Dow Jones Newswires; 202-862-6692; Judith.Burns@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 12:00 ET (16:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) The Striking Price: Position-Building Strategies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Be strong, and of good courage.   The sharp decline in the Dow industrials has priced many good stocks at attractive levels -- at least compared with recent prices. Sophisticates will sneer that stocks may snap lower once more, but isn't that how positions are built, and why so many investors use yield-enhancing options strategies like overwriting to manage stock positions? Clearly, many investors bought into the stock market's decline on Thursday. That's one reason why the Dow closed down 310 points rather than down 400 or more points. At Credit Suisse, there were even reports of buyers of short-dated calls in the S&P 500 SPDR (ticker: SPY) and Select Sector Energy SPDR (XLE). To be sure, Friday's decline demonstrates it's still a nervous market   Investors who believe the selloff is overdone should consider buying January 2009 options on stocks that are exhibiting strength, often based on international revenue, and that are expected to lead the market as investors rotate out of what had been fast-growing small-capitalization stocks. The long-dated options contracts cost a fraction of the price of buying the underlying shares outright, and limit how much money is at risk.   Look at Coca-Cola's (KO) January 55 calls, recently trading at $4.70; Johnson & Johnson's (JNJ) January 60 calls for $7; General Electric's (GE) January 40 calls for $4.30, Altria's (MO) January 65 calls for $8.70, and Verizon Communications' (VZ) January 42.50 calls at $5.40. All the options expire in January 2009.   A 25% increase in the stock price should, by some calculations, produce a 100% return in the original options position.   Another strategy is selling puts against stocks. Investors will realize a juicy premium because put prices are high, reflecting investor fear. Yes, the stocks could fall below the puts' strike price if the market rout continues, but these recommendations are meant for investors who use options to better navigate the market, rather than for traders.   Another stock to consider -- either for outright purchase or the purchase of a long call -- is Interactive Brokers (IBKR), parent of Timber Hill, a giant options market-making firm. The firm benefits in high-volatility markets, and a slowdown in leveraged buyouts lessens the chance of "front running" deals that costs it money.   In a trader's market -- where pricing volatility is more important than the possession of good information -- Interactive Brokers could trade higher. The firm reported second-quarter earnings Wednesday that were in line with investor expectations. More important, the stock rose on a day when the financial sector was sunk.   The key now is to stay calm, turn off the TV and readjust portfolio risk profiles when opportunities arise, ideally in advance of selloffs.   ---   E-mail: steve.sears@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Plugged In: Tiny Rival Takes Aim At Akamai
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Akamai Technologies' pain might be internap's gain.   Akamai's shares (ticker: AKAM) got whacked more than 20% last Thursday, after revealing that margins in its Internet content-delivery-network, or CDN, business could be shrinking, and that order growth is cooling.   But tiny Internap appears to be steadily heating up. The Suwanee, Ga.-based company, a recent entry into CDN -- systems of computers networked together across the Internet that deliver media and text -- has predicted 30% earnings growth for 2007, higher profits and gross margins of about 50% for all of its businesses, and higher margins in CDN.   Internap (INAP) is slated to announce earnings Tuesday, and based on its recent turnaround and penchant for raising targets under new management, it wouldn't be a stretch to see the company cast a rosier outlook for the second half of 2007. That could lift the stock, which, at 13 and change, is down from around 20 early this year.   "We're really moving in the right direction," says CEO Jim DeBlasio, who came off then-struggling Internap's board in November 2005 to become CEO.   CDNs are hot, thanks to torrid Internet-traffic growth driven by demand for rich media like online video. Think YouTube.   Akamai is the 800-pound gorilla in CDNs.   On the other hand, 11-year-old Internap is an Internet-services play that recently entered the CDN business through its recent acquisition of VitalStream. It's a distant third behind Limelight Networks (LLNW), which just went public in June and is embroiled in a patent squabble with Akamai.   Limelight is the primary reason for Akamai's pain. The upstart has been slashing prices in order to disrupt and take share from the incumbent. Limelight shares are trading around 17, well off their June high of 24.33, largely because of the price war.   Only 10% of Internap's $192.3 million in sales currently come from CDN. The rest is from its core Internet-routing optimization and data-center hosting businesses. The company, which sports a $667 million market cap, differentiates itself from the other two by bundling its services -- Internet trafficking and CDN -- and selling them to customers that already outsource their data-center operations with Internap. Internap also can fetch higher prices because it offers better quality and reliability, contends DeBlasio, a former Lucent exec.   DeBlasio and his team act as if they intend to become a multibillion-dollar sales company. "My plan is to go after [Akamai]," he says. "We offer what they can't deliver: reliability."   Internap got its start selling Internet-routing services using proprietary software that guarantees timely arrival of Internet content with 100% reliability, using the networks of major phone carriers like AT&T. Now, Internap has applied that same software to its VitalStream CDN services -- with the same guarantee. Thus, when customers like Disney stream a TV show to Internet users or when American Airlines sells a ticket, Internap pledges that the delivery won't get interrupted and that the quality won't be shaky, jerky or slow.   That's why DeBlasio thinks he doesn't need to lower his CDN prices and can protect margins. His customers can't afford disrupted content delivery at any price.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Key Family Member Now Favors Dow Jones Sale To News Corp -NYT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The deliberations of the Bancroft family over whether to sell Dow Jones & Co. Inc. (DJ) to Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. (NWS) took several bizarre turns Friday as family members switched sides, sniped at one another and even sought to change the terms of the offer and of their own family trusts, the New York Times reported in its Saturday edition.   William C. Cox Jr., one of the Bancroft family elders who control the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, has switched positions and now favors the sale, the Times reported, citing a person close to the family.   Adding confusion to an already murky vote, some representatives of the so-called Denver trusts, which control about 9% of the company's voting shares, are holding out for a higher price than the $60 a share that the Dow Jones board agreed to accept, the newspaper also reported, as did The Wall Street Journal on Friday.   The Wall Street Journal and the Times reported that on a separate front, family lawyers are trying to change the voting structure of the biggest family trust in order to allow family members to vote their shares independently. That trust, unlike some others, including the Denver trust, could be voted on only as a block.   The new structure would allow Christopher Bancroft, a Dow Jones board member and a vocal opponent of Murdoch's offer, to vote his shares against the deal and his relatives to vote for it if they wished. Bancroft controls a large block of shares - 14.5% of the total vote as of January - as both owner and as a family trustee.   Cox, a former Dow Jones executive, opposed the offer for months but recently began to waver, other family members said, according to the Times. Still, as recently as a family meeting last Monday, he appeared ready to vote against it, they said.   Calls by the Times to Cox's homes in Massachusetts and Florida were not returned. The person who said his position had changed could not offer an explanation for the shift.   Cox, 76, had formed, along with his sister, Jane Cox MacElree, the major bloc most firmly against selling the company to Murdoch. Cox and his wife and their children are said by people briefed on the family's workings to control about 8% of the Dow Jones shareholder vote, either as owners or trustees; MacElree controls about 15%.   The Bancroft family and its trusts hold 64% of the Dow Jones shareholder vote. Close to half the vote is opposed to a sale, some is in favor, and some is still wavering. Most of the outside shareholders are expected to approve the deal.   Michael B. Elefante, an adviser to the family and the primary trustee of the Bancroft trusts, told the special negotiating committee of the Dow Jones board that, based on his consultations with family members, the decision was still too close to call, the Times reported, citing a person with knowledge of the board's deliberations who asked not to be named because he was not authorized to comment publicly. This person added that Elefante, a lawyer at the Boston firm of Hemenway & Barnes, indicated the family was "knocking on the door" of approving the deal.   In addition to this and other newswires, Dow Jones publishes The Wall Street Journal and its international and online editions, Barron's, the Far Eastern Economic Review, MarketWatch, Dow Jones Indexes and the Ottaway group of community newspapers. Headline: Barron's(7/30) Battling The Beast Of Volatility
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   If the options market could make a movie about the stock market's recent performance, it might be titled The Dangerous Game. As in an Ingmar Bergman film, someone would be playing chess with a crafty apparition; his name would be Volatility. But unlike in some of the great auteur's movies, darkness wouldn't necessarily prevail; options would actually give investors a chance of thwarting their malicious opponent.   The preferred options -- for everyone these days exceptperhaps investors in Apple -- would be defensive puts, which give their holders the right to sell a stock at a certain price over a specified period, even if the shares actually are trading well below that price on the open market. Name the sector, name the stock, and put buying is now the defining trade.   How nervous is this market? The Chicago Board Options Exchange's Market Volatility Index (VIX) is currently at 24.17, well above the 12 and 13 levels of just a few months ago.   Some of the moves in the volatility chess game can be straightforward -- like buying puts on the iShares Russell 2000 (ticker: IWM) -- an exchange-traded fund. This is the trade du jour for panicked U.S. portfolio managers because the stocks in this ETF -- unlike those of the S&P 500, which includes large multinationals -- have little international exposure. The IWM is thus a pure-play way to bet on a declining U.S. market; trading volume has become immense. On Thursday, when the stock market was hammered, 1.5 million IWM puts changed hands; on a typical day, the total might be 465,000 or so.   The Russell 2000 put trade has become so popular because it is cheaper than actually shorting the ETF, and offers more leverage. Perhaps more important, the risk in buying a put is limited to the price paid for it, whereas shorting exposes investors or traders to unlimited risk if the market zigs rather than, as they expect, zags.   Another way for the average investor to play this jumpy market is with options tied to specific sectors or stocks.   Citigroup's derivatives strategists are advising clients that the selloff seen last week was overdone. They suggest betting that implied volatility among financial stocks -- currently at levels not seen in at least three years -- is too high, despite worries about subprime mortgage defaults, investment banks unable to sell debt to finance leveraged buyouts, a collapsing dollar and other unpleasant developments.   In the Select Sector Financial SPDR (XLF), which is a proxy for financial stocks, 26-week implied volatility was recently at 34%, double its historical level. That means that this exchange-traded fund was gyrating through a price range twice as broad as it usually does.   Andrew Wolchek, a Citigroup derivatives analyst, argues that the financial sector has been unfairly singled out by jittery investors and traders. And he cites the bank's chief U.S. equity strategist as noting that, historically, it hasn't paid for investors to sell shares of investment banks, brokers or asset managers when spreads between Treasury securities and other bonds widen, as they now are doing.   So in a client note published Wednesday, he recommended selling puts on financial stocks that Citi's analysts have Buys on. Among them: Merrill Lynch (MER), Morgan Stanley (MS), Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wachovia (WB).   This strategy is especially appealing to those who want to buy the stocks anyway, because the money received from selling a put effectively reduces the cost of purchasing the shares. But if the stock slides below the put's strike price -- exactly what has happened to most of the recommended stocks since Citigroup published its recommendation -- the party on the other end of the trade can force you to buy the shares at a price higher than what the stock currently is commanding.   Anyone who wants to cast the dice, however, should sell puts with strike prices near the stock price and that expire within three months; pick the options with the plumpest prices.   Citi is also recommending that index traders consider selling options on the S&P 500, which has significant financial-sector exposure, and buying options on the Nasdaq 100 index, which doesn't have such exposure, to create a hedged position.   Chances to make more daring -- and potentially more rewarding -- moves in the volatility chess game abound. But they're riskier and complicated and thus better suited for pros or very sophisticated individual investors, rather than the typical little guy trying to make a buck in a jumpy stock market.   One strategy is to sell near-the-money options straddles or strangles and to hedge these bets by buying stock. Citigroup likes this strategy for the Select Sector Financial SPDR and the shares of Merrill, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, JPMorgan and Wachovia. (In a straddle, an investor has both a put and a call with the same price and expiration date. In a strangle, the call and put have different prices.)   To be sure, such trades aren't for the faint-hearted. But when markets move toward extremes, boldness and aggressiveness can be virtues.   History shows that the best time to make money is usually when the market is most exuberant or most afraid. It's also the riskiest time. "You want to do it when the stuff is hitting the fan," says Jon Najarian of optionmonster.com, a trading advisory firm. And this seems like one of those times.   ---   (See related article: Ouch! -- Barron's July 30, 2007)   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Pearl Grp's Osmond Boosts Resolution Life Stake To 15.85%-FT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--The privately-held Pearl Group said Friday it had secured a 15.85% interest in Resolution Life - putting entrepreneur Hugh Osmond, Pearl Group's owner, in a position to question Resolution on its planned GBP8 billion merger with life assurer Friends Provident PLC (FP.LN), the Financial Times reported on its Web site.   Resolution PLC (RSL.LN), run by Clive Cowdery, is to meet shareholders next week to try to convince them to support its planned merger with Friends. Osmond and Cowdery spoke by telephone Friday, according to the FT. The investor meetings are now expected to include Osmond, the FT said.   Shares in Resolution rose nearly 3% to 659 1/2 pence on expectations of an offer from Osmond. Shares in Friends, meanwhile, fell 1 1/2 pence to 180 pence, with 88 million shares changing hands, the FT said.   A number of Resolution shareholers are seen as uncomfortable with the Friends merger because it is a departure from the original strategy of buying closed funds that no longer write new policies. In the past three years, Osmond and Cowdery have often fought as rivals buying up such funds.   One of Resolution's options is seen as moving from structuring the merger with Friends as a "scheme of arrangement," rather than an outright merger. Such a move would require 75% of shareholder votes, but appears faster than an outright offer, which requires only 50% of shareholder votes to be approved.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 17:05 ET (21:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Investors, Shareholders To Settle Lawsuits To Block TXU Sale
Story: DALLAS (AP)--TXU Corp. (TXU) says the investors buying the electric utility have settled shareholder lawsuits that aimed to block the power producer and electric utility's $32 billion sale, which would be the largest private buyout ever.   The agreement was reached Monday, according to a regulatory filing made this week by TXU. If approved by the courts, the settlement would remove a hurdle to the deal, which faces a Sept. 7 vote of TXU shareholders.   TXU announced in February that its board had agreed to sell the company to investors led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. and Texas Pacific Group.   Within weeks, several lawsuits were filed in state and federal court against TXU and its directors, claiming they failed look out for the interests of shareholders in agreeing to the deal.   The plaintiffs, who were seeking class-action status for their cases, said TXU directors had divided loyalties because they stood to gain from the sale to the KKR-TPG group.   All of the cases in state court were combined, and a judge in Dallas dismissed them, according to TXU's lawyers at the firm of Fulbright & Jaworski.   Monday's agreement between KKR-TPG investors, TXU and some of the plaintiffs would result in dismissing all the merger-related lawsuits if the courts approve, according to the filing.   Under the deal, TXU would not pay anything to the plaintiffs. But the buyers agreed that TXU would pay $925 million instead of $1 billion if it broke off the deal, and they made other changes in the proxy statement sent to shareholders, TXU said in the filing.   The sale the KKR-TPG group would require approval by two-thirds of TXU shareholders.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 10:33 ET (14:33 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: Some bargain-hunters have been attracted to financial stocks. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America are trading for under 10 times estimated 2007 profits, and B of A carries a bond-like dividend yield of 5.3%. The major Street firms all command less than 10 times projected 2007 earnings.   Among the key issues for Goldman, Lehman, Bear Stearns (BSC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) is what kind of losses will be incurred from the LBO fallout. Is $22 a share a normal level of earnings for Goldman?   Bear Stearns could be the biggest bargain on the Street because its shares, which fell 8.2%, to 123.13, last week, now trade for just 1.3 times its recent book value of $92.50 a share. Headline: Barron's(7/30) European Trader: Siemen's New Boss At Work
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Ardindam Nag   Siemens' new CEO, Peter Loescher, has started his job with a bang. But long-term investors can't be blamed for feeling a bit miffed.   Within a month of his appointment, he has plunged into the complex task of reallocating capital within the sprawling German industrial company, a task begun with gusto by his predecessor, Klaus Kleinfeld. Loescher clinched the sale of automotive unit VDO for 11.4 billion euros. But he immediately spent a little less than half of that on Dade Behring, a U.S. clinical diagnostic business, an acquisition announced Wednesday. On top of that, Siemens (ticker: SI) plans to retire a convertible bond.   Rather than earmarking some of the proceeds of the VDO sale for a special dividend for shareholders, Siemens is using it to purchase Dade at $77 a share, a price equivalent to a jaw-dropping 44 times estimated 2007 earnings. That's almost double the multiple of Dade's closest competitor, Beckman Coulter (BEC), which generates similar returns for investors. Dade's return on equity is 14%, compared with Beckman's 13.5%.   True, Dade was being shopped around. It would have been a fit with several other companies like Beckman, Bayer, Abbott, Becton Dickinson and Johnson & Johnson. By paying a 33% premium over its recent share price, Siemens should stave off a competing bid. But including Dade, Siemens has now done three deals for around 10.7 billion euros in the sector, generating an annual 3.3 billion euros in extra medical-equipment revenue. To cover Siemens' cost of capital of 8%, these investments will have to generate at least 1.22 billion euros in yearly operating earnings.   Current margins in the sector vary from 12% to 15%. So to cover the cost of capital, Siemens would have to increase sales to nearly 9 billion euros in seven years. That's equivalent to an annual growth rate of 15%, well above the growth in gross domestic product in major developed countries.   At Dade, Siemens is looking at only modest cost savings of 160 million euros, around 9% of Dade's 2006 cost base, by 2010. Returns on the investment are unlikely to exceed Siemens' cost of capital before then.   Strategically, getting Dade to mesh with the rest of Siemens' medical- equipment division won't necessarily be easy, either. The German company's current portfolio focuses on immunodiagnostics, while the U.S. company makes hemostasis and microbiology equipment. Siemens caters to a high-volume market; Dade addresses lower-volume segments.   Siemens should benefit from distributing Dade products in Germany, where the U.S. company has no presence, as well as bringing some global punch to Dade's rollout of Dimension Vista, an integrated medical-analysis tool that received clearance from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration two years ago. Dade has just started shipping Vista, which has blockbuster potential. The equipment can do up to 150 tests an hour, and deliver results online and to mobile devices.   But even assuming that Siemens does integrate Dade smoothly and that new products prove to be hits, CEO Loescher's task of making Siemens' recent investments pay their way looks challenging.   ---   ARINDAM NAG, who is based in London, is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                         DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES     Region/   Country   DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global      Point   Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,       Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Barron's(7/30) Where The Bond Buys Are
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   Interview With Edward Marrinan   Chief Credit Strategist, JPMorgan Securities     As director of North American credit strategy at JPMorgan Securities, Edward Marrinan has the unenviable task of making applesauce out of the fixed-income market's bad apples, a category that currently includes subprime mortgages and collateralized debt obligations -- bonds repackaged as new bonds. But dealing with pureed credits is nothing new to the bond-market veteran, who's been at JPMorgan since 1993. Here, he offers his views on opportunities and perils in the debt market.     Barron's: The Dow industrials sputtered last week, but that's after hitting 14,000, and Treasuries have seen a nice bid. Why should an investor look at a corporate bond fund?   Marrinan: To be perfectly frank, it's hard to be enthusiastic about the credit market's short-term outlook in that a variety of threats and risks are on the horizon.     Q: Yet the economy is perking up, as evidenced by strong second-quarter growth in GDP of 3.4%, and corporate profits look OK.   A: Yes, and we expect they are going to look pretty good for the second quarter. Earnings really aren't the issue or challenge right now. And leveraged positions in corporate balance sheets, the liquidity on corporate balance sheets in terms of cash flow, and cash balances are all at or near historically strong levels. A real challenge, however, is the subprime problem, which is sizable and very hard for a lot of our market participants to gain comfort about, because it is really hard to identify the points of risk, the concentrations of risk in the system.     Q: And there appears to be contagion.   A: For sure. That's contributing to the current weakness and the selloff that we are seeing, pretty much across the credit complex.     Q: Yet at the same time, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke says that fighting inflation is the No. 1 priority.   A: With pretty good reason. The economy is benefiting from resurgent momentum after a three-quarter lull that kind of reached its trough in the first quarter. But we anticipate that we are going to see a very steady resumption of economic activity.     Q: Europe is raising rates, as is Japan. One big thing that has helped the credit markets has been foreign inflows. Are these inflows going to continue with the dollar in a free fall?   A: Great question. A recent Treasury International Capital Flows report, though a lagging indicator, showed a record inflow of international buying or record demand from international sources for dollar-denominated fixed-interest corporate product.     Q: There appears to be dramatic change sentiment, spurred in part by the housing-sector slump, the subprime-mortgage mess, two Bear Stearns hedge-fund blowups and a pullback in leveraged loans. Do you agree?   A: Absolutely. Sentiment has taken a nose dive. Risk aversion is now the order of the day. Pricing is being dictated by buyers, rather than by sellers, of risk, and as a result we are seeing a pretty meaningful repricing across the entire spectrum of risk assets. Credit [worries] and subprime are very clearly contributing to that. A further factor weighing on sentiment and, by extension, valuations, is the forward calendar of leveraged finance deals that have to be funded.     Q: We've seen several pulled recently. That's why, I assume, you're saying we've got a buyer's market.   A: That is certainly part of it. We reckon that somewhere close to $300 billion of leveraged finance of one form or another is fairly visible, on a three-month horizon.     Q: That's a big problem for investment-grade-bond money managers. They've had to deal not only with leveraged buyouts, in which a bond that was rated double-A suddenly is a single-B, but stock buybacks, which are at a furious level and often come at the expense of bond holders. Special dividends are often funded by debt as well.   A: An interesting adjective: furious. I think companies are happy about it, and shareholders thrilled about it. It is only bondholders who are furious. In our opinion, we are at sort of the apex of this event-risk cycle right now. I find these kind of events objectionable when they bolster or maximize shareholder value at the expense of the bondholder. At the very other extreme is the leveraged-buyout phenomenon. It's probably the ultimate expression of shareholder-value maximization and, again, it is the nightmare scenario for credit investors, who are buried under a tidal wave of new debt.     Q: So, where do bond investors hide?   A: There are sectors that have low or limited likelihood of LBO activity. They include, for the most part, financial -- heavily regulated large-cap financial institutions, insurance companies, broker/dealers -- plus energy and utility companies.     Q: Investment-grade new issuance has been running at a record pace, too, hasn't it?   A: Correct.     Q: Why aren't these guys asking for tighter loan covenants? It's starting to happen a little bit, but it's still not what you would expect, given the nightmares that these money managers face.   A: Don't discount the progress that has been made on that front, particularly for investment-grade participants. We have seen over the last, I would say, 12 months -- perhaps a little bit longer -- a decided increase in the use of change-of-control covenants, which effectively protect the credit investor, giving him a put in most cases at 101 [$1.01 on the dollar], if there is a [buyout, takeover or merger] at a bond issuer.     Q: Meaning an owner has the right to sell the bonds back to the company?   A: Yes. A number of high-profile and very-large-cap companies have used change in control, including Home Depot [ticker: HD] with a number of bond issues back in December of 2006, and Alcoa [AA] in January of 2007.     Q: Yield margins across all fixed-income assets have been at historically narrow levels for several years. Where do you see the best return?   A: Well, the best return right now is frankly in the high-yield segment. Credit spreads in high yield are in the range of 435 to 445 basis points over Treasuries. [A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.] They have corrected, just like every other credit class, over the past four to six weeks. But they've corrected from an historically tight level achieved in June around 263 basis points. High yield may offer one of the more compelling risk/reward tradeoffs for credit investors right now.     Q: You mentioned the default rate, which has been 1% or so and been historically low for a fairly long time. Will it go up in the high-yield corporate-bond sector?   A: Corporate defaults eventually will rise, but we don't expect that to be much of a threat over the next 12, 18 or even 24 months.     Q: How about investment-grade paper? What should investors do there?   A: In the investment-grade world, we for some time have been recommending that investors concentrate on areas that are defensive or at least insulated from the worst effects of the kind of event risk we were talking about earlier. The financial sector . . . still has lots of financial flexibility and that's always a good thing for credit investors. Other sectors that we think are interesting are more defensive. The idea here for many investors is to avoid significant losses from blowup events like LBOs or leverage recapitalizations. That would suggest utility companies, energy companies and select telecom, media and entertainment companies that have already seen much of the event risk they are likely to be exposed to in this cycle.     Q: OK, so you see the fixed-income markets in for some near-term trouble. Longer term, you're more optimistic, right?   A: We are guardedly sanguine. Subprime is going to be hurtful, but not devastating. We have some concern about the funding calendar. It is very hard to know right now whether all of those deals will be funded successfully and whether any failed deals will have a ripple effect. If we can negotiate [past these dangers] with a manageable amount of difficulty or damage, we may set the stage for firmer conditions in our market afterwards.     Q: What specifically in the economy are you looking closely at?   A: The major wild card is what the Fed's next step will be. If there is a resurgence in inflationary pressure, it seems clear that the Fed is prepared to resume hiking interest rates at least a couple or three more times, 25 basis points each time.     Q: Where do you expect the fed-funds rate to be at year end? And what do you see 10-year Treasuries yielding by then?   A: Our economists expect to see the Fed forced back into a tightening mode for only a temporary period. And the house view is that we will see a hike in December that will lift the fed-funds rate to 5.50%, possibly followed, if necessary, by two more 25-basis-point moves to a peak of 6%, maybe by the end of next year's first quarter. As for Treasury yields, we're looking for a back-up into the range of 5 1/2% toward the end of this year from 4.77% now.     Q: What specific names in the credit markets do you like?   A: The names we like would offer some good protection for credit investors. Certain names in the health-care sector offer pretty interesting value. This is a classically defensive sector, although one that has been somewhat prone to event risk with various LBOs and leveraged shareholder-friendly events.   Bonds from companies like Aetna [AET], Universal Health Services [UHS], WellPoint [WLP], Marsh & McLennan [MMC], Willis Group Holdings [WSH] all fit the bill. In the financial space, we like Janus Capital [JNS]. It recently borrowed some money in the corporate bond market, but it's also been one of the most active users of protective covenants that help bond investors. In the energy world, we like the old Kinder Morgan Energy [KMP] bonds. Its valuations look attractive, even though the company has kind of restructured itself through an LBO.     Q: Any others?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Follow-Up: DuPont Will Get Its Formula Right
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Thomas G. Donlan   DuPont, which had been humming along nicely since our favorable feature ("DuPont: Ready to Bloom," Nov. 20), slipped last week after reporting flat earnings in the second quarter. Revenues were in line with consensus estimates, but DuPont surprised investors with earnings of $1.01 a share, not counting a favorable one-time tax adjustment worth three cents a share; the consensus from analysts had been $1.06 a share. In a classic Wall Street overreaction, the stock (ticker: DD) fell $3 on the news of the two-cent miss, to a shade under 50.   The Wilmington, Del., chemical giant, a component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, blamed lower growth in North America, particularly in its product lines sold to housing and automotive customers, and higher input costs for energy and chemical stocks linked to the price of oil. The company noted higher sales volume in foreign markets -- a benefit of the falling dollar for all U.S. companies operating in Europe, Canada and other places with rising currencies.   CEO Charles "Chad" Holliday Jr.  reaffirmed the company's $3.15-a-share earnings guidance for the full year, despite projecting continuing disappointment in housing and auto markets.   "We generated solid volume growth in all regions outside the United States, and increased local selling prices for the 14th consecutive quarter while reducing fixed costs as a percentage of sales," he said. "We are executing our growth strategies and continuing to increase return on invested capital."   Analysts had been expecting big gains in sales of corn seed that's resistant to herbicides, because there's such strong demand for corn to make ethanol -- but the 12% sales gain was restricted by available supply. The head of the agricultural unit said there will be increased supply for the next crop year. Another problem in the unit: Gains in corn acreage were offset by reduced acreage and reduced sales for other crops, such as soybeans.   Once the bluest of blue chips, DuPont has been restructuring for a decade, and the job continues. The stock was trading last November at $47.63, and had reached within two points of the 55 target that bulls on the stock were looking for at that time.   After the two-cent earnings miss reported Tuesday, the stock fell to 49.90, and it continued lower on Wednesday and Thursday, to about 48. The disappointment -- and its roots in two of the company's key markets -- makes it harder to maintain a bullish outlook, but DuPont should eventually deliver on its biotech promise, and it remains a solid investment. The stock could again make a run at 55 and, in the meantime, it pays a 3% dividend.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:03 ET (04:03 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(7/30) Hedge Funds: Managed Futures: Changing Course: Becalmed No More
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Greg Newton   If the investment world has a Rodney Dangerfield, it's managed futures.   Disrespected for their allegedly exorbitant costs, their perceived riskiness, their widespread reliance on inscrutable black-box trading systems and all manner of other things, these funds bear a heavy burden: almost five consecutive years of  underperformance against just about every equity benchmark.   But a funny thing has happened on the way to hell. The assets invested in managed futures, now widely regarded as a subset of the hedge-fund universe, have more than tripled since 2002, the last year they beat the S&P 500. As of March 31, investors had an estimated $172 billion in this sector, according to Barclay Trading Group, a data provider based in Fairfield, Iowa. One reason: The markets appear to be becoming more volatile, and managed futures thrive on volatility.   Just look at what's happened to the John W. Henry & Co. Financial and Metals Portfolio. On March 31, it was down almost 20% for 2007 and in the midst of a three-year, 40% slump that was the longest and one of the deepest in its 22-year history. The decline and resulting investor redemptions, cost the firm -- controlled by John W. Henry, principal owner of the Boston Red Sox -- more than 80% of its assets, which now stand at little more than $500 million.   In the second quarter, however, the portfolio surged 25%. Ironically, Merrill Lynch (MER) ended a long-term relationship with Henry in April and pulled its mostly retail investors' assets out of his fund -- almost exactly at the portfolio's nadir.   Henry declined to comment for this article. But his managed-futures operation certainly wasn't alone in performing poorly over most of the three past years. Barclay Trading Group founder Sol Waksman, who has followed managed futures since 1985, says this span was the most unusual he's seen. Other than funds that invested heavily in energy, none seemed to have a trading strategy that worked well, regardless of whether their focus was long-term (which in this world means several months) or short-term (a week or a day).     "Performance hasn't been good, and once upon a time, that would have meant big redemptions and people going out of business. Instead, we've seen this huge growth in assets, and those new investors being willing to stay committed," Waksman observes. "Perhaps they've got the message about the strategy's diversification benefits" for investors in stocks and bonds.   And perhaps some of it is a perception disconnect. Managed futures are widely viewed as a proxy for commodities. Its managers are regulated as "commodity-trading advisers" and "commodity-pool operators" ultimately by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Yet it's been a long time since commodities dominated the holdings of advisers specializing in managed futures.   The long-running Campbell & Co. FME Large strategy -- the acronym stands for financials, metals and energy -- currently has about a third of its $10 billion-plus assets in currencies, and much of the rest in roughly equal chunks of stock indexes and interest-rate instruments. Commodities rarely account for more than 20% of its positions.   Many commodity markets are simply too small to accommodate the positions that large managers need to move the needle. In fact, few managers overseeing more than $1 billion trade as much as half their assets in commodities, including the more liquid energy and precious metals. Most of those with $2 billion or more are heavily weighted toward the deeper, more liquid, financial-instrument market.   Although the going has been challenging for managed-futures managers over the past few years, some have excellent long-term records. Among them: Renaissance Technologies, a New York-based quantitative shop founded by James Simons. Its Renaissance Medallion Fund, long closed to new investors and essentially a managed-futures vehicle, has returned more than 35% annually for almost 20 years, after subtracting a very hefty 5% management fee and a 44% incentive fee on any profits.   Renaissance is gearing up to open a new managed-futures fund in the fall. (Simons declined to comment for this article, citing regulatory concerns.) In early July, the industry newsletter Hedge Fund Alert reported that the new vehicle is designed to manage up to $25 billion, and would take a longer-term approach than famously frenetic Medallion. It's reportedly modeled on the Renaissance Institutional Equities Fund, which has amassed about $30 billion in assets in barely two years. The projected size of the fund implies that it will trade only the most liquid futures markets around the world.   The new fund probably offers a range of fee structures less startling than Medallion's, and even the sector's standard 2/20 structure -- 2% management, 20% incentive. Renaissance Institutional Equities Fund's fees range from a fixed 2%, with no incentive fee, up -- or down -- to an option of a fixed fee of 0.5%, along with an incentive fee of 35% for any gains over the Standard & Poor's 500 index's (dividends included).   To invest in the new fund, investors will have to shell out a very sizable minimum sum -- Renaissance Institutional Equities demands $25 million. Some financial institutions provide access to that product through pooled vehicles with lower, although still substantial, minimums, but it's unclear whether Renaissance will allow that for the new fund.   In less rarified air, long-standing efforts to make managed futures more accessible, and less expensive, for retail and "mass-affluent" investors are finally putting products on the investment shelves. Historically, those investors got in through retail-brokerage offerings that larded rich layers of additional cost, including sales charges and management fees, onto the strategy's already high fee structure.     Futures obligate participants to sell or buy commodities or financial instruments at a specific time, and they allow them to make big leveraged bets, which can be dangerous if they backfire. Relatively few individuals trade futures on their own, viewing them as too risky.   Asset Alliance, a New York-based boutique, has announced plans for a hybrid closed-end fund aiming to replicate the Barclay Group's BTOP50, an index reflecting the net trading performance of 23 large trading advisers. The fund will require only a $10,000 minimum, and even allow monthly redemptions, at net asset value. Designed to be sold through a network of wealth managers and brokerages, the fund is expected to be launched in October.   In March, the Rydex Managed Futures Fund (RYMFX) became the first conventional mutual fund to use a managed-futures strategy. With a $2,500 minimum investment, daily liquidity, a 1% redemption fee on shares owned for less than 90 days and a 1.65% expense ratio, it's already attracted $150 million in assets.   Instead of investing in managed-futures advisers, it aims to replicate the performance of the S&P Diversified Trends Indicator, a long-short futures investment benchmark based on 24 U.S. exchange-traded contracts in 14 sectors, divided evenly among commodity and financial futures.   The DTI is based on technical indicators and is "positioned each month . . . based on price behavior, relative to its moving average" -- allowing it to capture profits in both up and down markets, according to an S&P white paper.   It claims, accurately, both low volatility and a low correlation with stocks and bonds. But it does include some rules that few, if any, managed-futures advisers would implement. For example, it doesn't invest in stock-index futures (thus reducing its correlation to the equities market), and it doesn't short energy issues, which can jump quickly on any inkling of tight supply.   Rydex says that that the pro forma risk-return profile of the DTI is more conservative than that of actively managed futures funds. Its annual compound return of 11%, with a 6% standard deviation (a measure of riskiness), compares with the BTOP50's yearly 9.44% return and 13.5% standard deviation over the past two decades.     Since the DTI went live in January 2004, it has outperformed the BTOP50, and its correlation with the S&P 500's total return remains extremely low, at just 2%. In contrast, the BTOP50's correlation with the stock-market benchmark has been almost 60% since 2004, undermining one of the most important selling points for managed futures -- diversification. (Over 10 years, the correlation is a negative 17%.)   Managed futures probably will never be a mainstream investment, but the availability of new ways to play them, combined with the return of market volatility, is bringing them more respect.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  July 28, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
